Considering gloss is the first word in the description I was very disappointed in the look of this vinyl. I didn't expect it to magically look like real CF but it looks like a sticker, very flat. Gonna have to find something else because this won't change the sea of dull black and grey in my car's interior. No shine at all. Fairly easy to work with though. Just time consuming.

Edit: Auto Vinyl Solutions/Ikonwraps is who I purchased this from. These people are the problem. They only carry the ca 421 di noc, and ship this in place of the ca 1170 gloss di noc. I contacted them saying I thought the wrong version was shipped to me and they just told me I was confused. When I called the phone number on the tube I was told that they haven't carried the gloss version for a while. These people are shady online. They blamed the mistakes on Metro Restyling for putting up product pictures. ???  The guy I talked to on the phone was very honest and helpful. Maybe the gloss version is glossy.  I'll have to order some to find out. I thought I already had. I'll update if the gloss is glossy. The 421 looks like and feels like a hologram card where the image shifts from different viewing perspectives.

Update 2
I decided to order the 1080 scotchprint instead. It's much easier to work with than the di noc but is also more delicate. If you want the glossy carbon fiber look get the scotchprint instead. Something else to consider is that the texture is much smoother on the scotchprint which will be much easier to clean. All those little grooves in the di noc pattern will collect dirt and oil. I don't see why anybody would use di noc in their car now that 3m has a better option. It looks better, is easier to work with and will clean much easier.

reviewText: I was very anxious to try these spark plugs after several recommendations. At first they where great. My truck started easier, ran smoother and even got better fuel economy like they advertise. I have a 2006 GMC Seirra and I got an average of over 20 mpg for the first time ever. I was really happy. BUT... With less than 5000 miles my truck started running poorer and poorer untill it couldn't even get up into my driveway. I had already given my truck a full tune up and I could not find the problem. I had my truck put on a flatbed and towed to the dealership. After about 10 minutes they pulled the spark plugs out and showed me my plugs that where clearly fouled. I didn't think to check them because they where new and the truck had ran so good with them at first. 5000 miles is way too short of a lifespan. The Tech at the Dealership wasn't surprised at all. He said that when he saw that the plugs where E3's, he decided that was the first thing he would check. All the plugs where fouled, not just one or two. I triple checked on E3's website to make sure that I had the right plugs for my truck and even checked the gap which was correct, which the way the plug is designed you can't change the gap anyway. My truck has OEM ACDelco's back in it and it runs fine. Save yourself some headaches and skip these.
Screws don't fit so I will be heading to the hardware store soon!
You can't even see the benz symbol, very dissapointed. Waste of money

I did tons of research and these mirrors got decent reviews.  I did not have a great experience with them. First off, no instructions for the wiring, no internet link or QR code scanner for a website to visit?  I had to spend quite awhile searching You Tube and the internet to find the color code and some basic instructions.

The driver side did not fit well at the top section I had to use a heat gun to force it into the groove by the window.  The mirrors look great, but passenger side seems to be angled different than the drivers, all mounts are identical. The side marker light seems very cheap and flimsy with the clip to lock it inside and all the wires are just hanging in view when the mirror is turned slightly, not locked behind wire holders present inside the mirrors.

I did not notice any issues with the mirrors not being flat or distorting. I have yet to hook up the heater for both mirrors, I have a 2002 Ford F250 with the stock basic power mirrors so it took several hours to wire up the mirrors correctly.  Time will tell if the mirrors hold up.
summary: Poorly constructed, feel cheap, no instructions for wiring 2002 Ford F250

I wrongly assumed that this tube would fit my lawn tractor's front tire, which had begun leaking.  After all, the size was right.  How could I go wrong?  Sadly, the stem is meant for a center hole--not the kind found of my tractor and most others on the market.  And forget removing one side from the rim (which I did to facilitate installation)--without the right setup you will never remount the tire.  I ended up taking it into a mower repair shop and had to fork out over $20 for a new tube and having the tire remounted.

Do not use this product.  Spend half the price and pick up some basic clear coat spray from walmart.  I had to remove (sand off) this quick coat after applying (after vht nightshades) to my taillights.  The nightshades worked fine, but this quick coat goes on foggy & does not maintain the desired "wet" look.  Avoid it.

The SAME double sided 3M tape for $5-10 depending on length (I decided to go with drilled holes and snap clips instead ... less messier, much more durable).

So essentially, I bought MORE of this "lip" for a FRACTION of the price at Lowe's. This company is a scam, they just buy the garage door bottoms for $10-15, stick some cruddy 3M tape on it, and turn it around to sell it to customers at **5** TIMES THE PRICE!!

I don't mind the whole repackaging idea with slight modifications so it is now usable for cars... its the fact that they have the AUDACITY to flip it around for a tremendous profit when the exact same material they repackage is so easily available to everyone if only they opened their eyes and looked at any home improvement store.

reviewText:
The box, instructions, and the product itself doesn't have the company's name anywhere. No number to call. I can't ask a question for this product on Amazon. Something doesn't feel right.

UPDATE: After installing these today, I was irritated that they did not lock into my fittings, had to use zip ties to secure them. They looked great at first glance, then I noticed that they were flickering. Not just one but both. I thought okay, I might be too picky. Got to my destination and noticed the lights were off, double checked that I had the light switch turned on. It was in fact on. Turned the high beams on and BOOM, they came on (still flickering). Got to my next destination and looked at them and they were off again! Same thing, turn high beams on and BOOM, they were on. Got back to my house, they were off again! Turned high beams on then back off and waited. Didn't take but one minute and they started turning off and on simultaneously, then both shut off. Thought to myself, these are going back to the manufacturer. I don't know, maybe I received a bad set. Maybe not. All I know is that my review is based on a verified purchase and no I did not receive these for free or a discounted price like the rest of them. I pulled full amount for what seems to be a total waste of money. I'll just stick with my plain Jane cheap halogens- at least they WORK. Take it from me, don't waste your money on these.

THIS IS NOT FORD MOTORCRAFT, NOT even close. I have been suckered too many times by these kinds of people, counterfeit parts in replica boxes. Go to your local FORD dealer for these parts. I promise you, You will see a difference. Notice the pictures never show you the front of the module..... Ever wonder what a true MOTORCRAFT part looks like, I just picked up my new one from the local dealer after being ripped off with 3 of these so called MOTORCRAFT parts. Ford ignition parts from the earlier generation of EFI are very sensitive. Your vehicle and your brain will thank you... These type of modules can be dead right out of the box, or cause slight to major misfiring and have you chasing your tail (after all you just put a new TFI on your car, right? Or did you just put a P.O.S. on your car?) The more expensive dealer price is cheap insurance that you got a good part that won't leave you walking.

reviewText:
I bought these thinking I'd save a little bit. Nope. Garbage. Had for ~2000 miles and ran over a small pothole. Nothing out of the ordinary... Then the clunking started. I had been riding with these broken for 500 miles and the clunking was absolutley INSANE. These are not high-quality parts. Save yourself the trouble, and buy OEM quality parts. I inspected my shock mounts, and this is what I found. The plastic bushing on the inside was COMPLETELY separated from the metal housing. I will not be buying URO parts again. I have some of their other parts in my car, and now I'm scared that they're going to go bad on me too!!
I want my money back.
See attached pictures of the damage.

I bought 3 cans of this stuff because it was highly advertised in my monthly auto magazines. I really love the Turtle Wax Black Tire Coat, but it's $12.99 for a 6 oz. can. Thought I'd try this to see if it came close to the performance of the Turtle Wax. It does not. Not even close. If you look at the original advertising for this product, right on the can it said "Last's 30 days guaranteed". Now look at the can as it's being sold now. It now says "Last's UP to 30 days". The word "UP" is the kicker here. That means it could last from 1 day up to 30, and it does what it claims. I tried this on my Durango, which I had previously used the Turtle Wax on. This stuff lasted about 3 days tops. It slung all over the side of my truck, looks horrible. I knew it wasn't as good as what I've been using when I sprayed it on, and it stayed wet. So of course it slung off. The Turtle wax LOOKS wet, but dries perfectly to a mirror like shine and does NOT come off until maybe 3 weeks after it's applied. I used one can of the Simoniz, I won't be using the other 2 cans. I went and bought more of the Turtle Wax. That stuff is expensive, but it works so it's cheaper in the long run. Save yourself some grief (wiping the splatter of the side of your vehicle) and skip this stuff. It's like 95% of the other tire shines on the  market. It doesn't last long and it slings onto your ride and makes it look horrible. I do recommend you give the Turtle Wax Black Tire Coat at least one try. I think you'll be impressed.

The color is typically a correct match, since Moeller has received the recipes from most of the OEMs. But that is where the "good" stops dead. I can only speak of my personal experience.

I have used "10's of cans" - on my 200 HP OceanPro Evinrude outboard. The paint is so thin, that any more than a mist will run on ANY surface - especially if it is vertical.  Fighting the temptation to spray on enough to actually "see" the color is difficult and usually you will get runs no matter what you try.

The former manufacturer that provided the OEM match-ups was "Tempo", which was marginally better, (because it could NOT be worse). Makes you wish Krylon had the contract.

I have considered many recommendations to use a professional painter and spray on Awlgrip or another decent-quality paint, but usually decide to wait another year due to the price difference. But this is an error on my part, becuase even if you DO manage to get the Moeller paint to coat evenly, it will be gone - or peeling off in spots - after one season. AND I am practicing proper prep, using Zinc Chromate primer - so don't even go THERE.

This is not complaining only to potential buyers.  I sent my experience in detail with photos to Moeller - without reply. So good luck to those of you who buy it anyway. It just seems wrong to me when it carries that "marine" cost to be so low in quality.
summary: No Game at all - is Better Than the ONLY Game in Town?

reviewText:
I purchased this pricey WeatherTech Easy-On Stone and Bug Deflector on Amazon two years ago and installed it on my Chevy Sierra.  I purchased it from WeatherTech because they're known for American made, quality merchandise and good customer service.  When it arrived, there were no instructions or fasteners.  The packaging was unimpressive, however the deflector was undamaged. I called WeatherTech and they sent fasteners and instructions within two days.  Their customer service was professional and responsive.

In the case of my vehicle, the installation was straight forward i.e., insert four plastic mounting nuts into four existing factory holes in the underside of the hood.  Place the guard on the hood and use four provided sheet metal screws and rubber grommets to secure the guard in place.  The product fits well, looks good and has an impressive finish.  The whole installation takes 10 minutes.

Over the following two years of use, I found the claim that these guards deflect bugs and stones from striking both your hood and windshield to be rather subjective as there's really no way to determine if they actually work.  I assume that they probably help to a minor degree just from their presence, but I suspect that most who buy these (included myself) would say that they work only because they don't want to admit that they bought it, installed it and found they couldn't determine if it served any real purpose other than to add some bling.

The reason for my low rating of this deflector is this:

The method by which it attaches to the vehicles hood is of a very poor design.  Within two years after installation, the plastic around all four of the attachment points fractured and eventually broke through.  Here's why:

Each time you close your hood the deflector takes an impact shock.  That shock must be absorbed by four small fastener points and, as a result, stresses the plastic around those points.  With each hood closure the shock is repeated and, eventually, the plastic around the attachment points shatter.  The installation instructions advise you to not over-tighten the screws (which I followed to the letter), but I view this warning only as an 'escape clause' on their part to relieve them from the liability of their poor design.  I threw mine away and again purchased the identical deflector, but this time from AVS, paying $20 less.

When I mounted the new guard I didn't follow their instructions.  Instead, instead I took a different approach.  I first applied 3M double-sided exterior adhesive tape to the hood where the guard makes contact.  I taped only those areas between the fastener heads to ensure that the entire surface area across the hood and guards contact points remained even and there were no high or low pressure points.  This is important so that no uneven stress points are created.  I put the guard in place, pressed it into the tape for a few minutes and found that it had a very solid feel, adhering firmly to the hoods surface along its entire length.  I inserted the four screws using four washers that I'd modified into 'long washers' by grinding down two sides, ending up with a long rectangular washer that spread the force of the screw head over a wider area of the guards surface.  I tightened these only to the point that the washer would not move under the screws head.  (The screws should only be viewed as a back up in the event that the tape fails.)  I let the tape cure and bond for 24 hours before closing the hood.  When I closed the hood, I noted a significant difference.  The guard felt like it was a part of the hood and very solid.  Hopefully, I'll get more use out of this one than I did the last.

A note regarding the WeatherTech Easy-On Stone and Bug Deflector:  WeatherTech does not make the hood guards they sell.  The WeatherTech logo is placed on their guards by the real manufacturer i.e., AVS - Lund International (Auto Vent Shade), which holds the patent for this particular design.  You can by this guard directly from AVS on Amazon for about $20 less.
summary: Poorly designed mounting points failed after two years.

I have sleep apnea and need something to power my machine while camping.  When I first found this I was excited.  The thing I wanted most was the ability to connect to an external battery.

The first one I had lost all power after one night of running a 10 watt (consumption)fan.  Called customer service, waited 35 minutes, was told to return it.

Second one I had, lost all power after one night of running a 10 watt light (consumption).  Tried hooking it up to the external battery, no difference.  Called customer service three times, first two times was on hold for 48, and 52 minutes respectively.  Both times I was told someone would get back to me since the person I was talking to didn't know the answer.  My questions were simple, a) why the quick draining, and b) why doesn't hooking up an external battery extend the life of the unit.

No one called back, and no one could answer.  I returned my second unit and am using a simple car lighter adapter and am having no problems.  I did have to buy a 100aH battery which was pricey, but can go a week no problem.

There are a lot of positive reviews here, but I would tell you to try calling customer service and seeing how long it takes them to respond.

I purchased these lights in October 2015.  I liked them and they installed easily.  I had no problem with the lights until I noticed water had intruded INSIDE the lights.  This was in January 2017.  These lights have a 1-year warranty and here I am 2-3 months beyond that when I noticed this issue.  Here in California we have had a severe drought throughout almost all of that warranty period.  Then in late 2016 and early 2017 we are now experiencing vast amounts of rain.  That's when the problem began....as soon as we started getting lots of rain.  I contacted the company, Auto Lights & Bulbs (which happens to be based here in California apparently), and described this issue.  I felt that given I was only a couple months past the warranty period & given the facts about the rain here in California, that they might replace them as a matter of good customer service.  The response was short: "Your over the 1-year warranty."  Not even a "sorry you had a problem."  I responded back asking for reconsideration given the circumstances.  After waiting several days I finally got a response which was basically the same.  I asked to be connected to a supervisor.  The company never responded back.  While I understand the 1-year warranty period and the need for a company to limit that time period, I strongly believe as a matter of customer service (given the facts as described) that Auto Lights & Bulbs should have replaced them.  The terse "your past the 1-year warranty,"  slow response to my inquiries and finally not providing me with supervisor contact information leaves a bad taste in my mouth.  Poor product and poor customer service.  If you decide to buy these from this company I strongly suggest buying some automotive silicone or other sealant and seal everywhere possible yourself since they apparently did not seal them properly.

reviewText:
These lights are a COMPLETE JOKE. The driving light circuit is extremely dim, and the brake light circuit disables the dim driving light circuit and only illuminates the tip of the light which is not so good compared to other LED lights on the market. I _strongly_ discourage anyone from ordering this product.

I have compared 3 different LEDs and here is my report:
"1157 Bay15D 18 SMD 5050" (Amazon item B004C8L1AE) I give this a 10 out of 10 for the driving light circuit, 9 out of 10 for the brake light circuit, and 10 out of 10 for flood/spread. This is by far my favorite light I've used. It is more pricy but it has the best performance. Both circuits are brighter than my original incandescent light bulb and it has EXCELLENT flood/spread of the light.
"1157 RED 48 LED Light" (Amazon item B002SD8BMQ) I give this a 7 out of 10 for the driving light circuit, a 10 out of 10 for the brake light circuit, and a 8 out of 10 for flood/spread. This is a great product but just as others have reported, they do not last long and many LEDs begin to stop working. Within 1 week the driving circuit of 1 of my bulbs stopped working, so I was at risk of getting a ticket for a missing tail light. As for the brake light circuit, it is very bright, even brighter than the SMDs listed above, but unfortunately also after just 1 week some of the LEDs would stop working and they of course would loose their brightness. I do not recommend these because they are UNRELIABLE. The driving light circuit is as bright or maybe slightly less bright than my original incandescent light bulb, but the brake light circuit is much brighter than my original incandescent light bulb. They do flood pretty well, but not as good as the SMDs which are much more reliable.
"1157 White 20 LED Light(2 bulbs) ba15d" (Amazon item B0017L7E9Q) I give this a 1 out of 10 for the driving light circuit, a 4 out of 10 for the brake light circuit, and a 1 out of 10 for flood/spread. (this is a white led version). These lights are complete GARBAGE. I cannot recommend these to anyone. They are a complete joke. Both circuits are less bright than my original incandescent light bulb, and they do not flood at all. They have the worst spread/flood, they are worthless. All you see when the brake circuit comes on is a very small diameter concentration of light at your brake lens, and for the driving light circuit you cannot even tell they are on unless it is very dark outside. I imagine you will get a ticket for not having bright enough driving lights. Horrible product, please do not purchase this. You do not have to learn the hard way.

Keep in mind that these LED light companies, in my experience, are very sneaky: They only give you 2 or 3 days to return these products. So you only have a very small window of time to receive, test, and then try to return them because they will likely not give you a refund at all.

In conclusion, pony up the extra bucks and get yourself a SMD-type LED bulb. SMDs are brighter, have the best light spread/flood, and are the most reliable. If you cannot afford SMD lights, then I think you should wait for the technology to become affordable because you will spend $$ on other lights that do not work or will not last, and then you will end up putting your original lights back in at a complete loss. Honestly, you should wait until you can afford SMD lights or not switch to LED lights at all. - My 2 cents
summary: These lights are a COMPLETE JOKE.

reviewText:
I had high hopes for this charger - its specs looked good on paper and price is reasonable.  But once I got it, I found that it uses too "aggressive" charging algorithm.

For instance, once I plugged it to a Motorcraft battery (it is installed in a car that was just driven for an hour), it starts applying increasingly high voltage - it starts from about 13V, and in several minutes got to almost 16V (I used a multimeter to access the voltage at the battery terminals).  The charger display would show 12V - irrespective of the actual voltage, so it does not help at all. In about 30 min the charger illuminated green LED signifying end of the charge, and kept about 16V in this "floating mode".

I used a different charger (B&D BC15BD) on the same "charged" battery afterwards, and it starts with classic "constant current, then top off with decreasing current" charging scheme, and it took about 12 hours (at 15A) to get to the top off stage, where it kept 14.7V at the battery for another  hour (with decreasing current)  to get to the floating mode.  So clearly those 2 chargers take a very different approach to the battery charging - now the question is which one to trust.

To figure this out, I used SC-1200A on a  different car battery (Toyota True Start)  - it  did not want to be charged this fast even at applied 16V, and to my horror I could hear boiling water  inside the tray, even after I limited charging current to 3A (!).  BC15BD used on the same battery did not exhibit this behavior, but took a long time to top if off.

At this point I decided to give up SC-1200A as it has too "aggressive" (16V is too high according to the many sources I could find on-line) and to my estimate a very inaccurate way to charge a car battery.

You get what you pay for.  These are one use pads at best for rubber wheels that will require a clean up. Try to save money and you buy twice.

reviewText:
Bought these for our race team in a pinch and like an idiot didn't test them.  Brought to the track, attempted to use during the race, they leaked terribly all weekend.  Further inspection showed that the edge of the neck was not flat but angled, therefore the way the cap would go on would never allow it to seal flat.  If you try to tighten harder it simply slipped off.

Came back home, emailed VP.  They admitted to having received a bad batch, took my info, said a replacement would arrive in a week.  Two weeks later, nothing, three weeks later, nothing.  Four weeks later I email them again.  I get a response another two weeks later, they apologize, indicate they are waiting on replacement to arrive to their warehouse, should be another two weeks.  Three months go by, I just about gave up.  But why not, email again.  A week later the jugs arrive.  I inspect them, the edge of the neck seems is about 3 mm thin in the same spot, on both, quality control is clearly lacking.  I test them with water, they work.  I test with fuel, they leak.  Trash, as suspected.

I go into the 'how do I fix this' mode.  Go to Home Depot (where else) and find the Everbilt Flush Valve Shank Washer, SKU 1000 055 036, in the toilet repair department for less than $2 a piece.  I place this washer gasket on top of the neck, and screw on the cap, it seals perfectly.  I test with fuel, no leaks.  Problem solved, no thanks to VP.
summary: I'll tell you how to fix these

Well made product BUT...DOES NOT fit on a Sahara with stock tires.  Adding a spring mount will cause the spring to sit against the spare.  The manufacturing is of as this mount positions the center line of the antenna way to close to the spare.  It should be centered between the spare and the window.  They had at least 1/2 inch of room to move this center line closer to the jeep.  Most if not all antenna "hits" will be while the jeep is moving forward.  This will cause the  antenna to flex backwards towards the spare tire.  The mount leave leaves less than 1/4 of an inch between the tire and antenna without the spring base.  With nowhere to go the antenna will likely crack.  Some people in some of the online forums have taken to putting the mount in a vice and then pounding it with a hammer to get it to be more centered.  No thanks.  My vendor here (not Amazon) suggested adding 1/2 inch spacer behind the spare mounting bolts.  But that would leave only 3 or 4 threads available to mount the spare.  So that won't work.  They were VERY good in accepting it back for a full refund.  Excellent customer service. Very disappointed in Teraflex engineering on this one.
summary: Do not mount to a Sahara with stock tires... see pics.

My 06 ML350 requires an oil change once every 15000 miles or once a year, whichever comes first. So after one year/10,000miles of this filter in my truck, it was time for a change. Imagine my surprise when I saw the K&N oil filter was CRUSHED, the pleats were folded flat against one another.

I like to consider all possibilities, and be fair in my reviews. It is POSSIBLE the filter was fully clogged with dirt, thus causing the oil pressure to crush it, which means it is possible the 10,000 miles I put on it was too much, or the filter simply doesn't have enough filtration capacity. But K&N should know and design for the 15,000 mile service interval Mercedes calls for.

That said, my full synthetic Mobil 0W-40 was quite dark and considering the short distance nature of my driving habits, I'll be increasing the frequency of both my oil and filter changes, but my filter won't be a K&N.

reviewText: I'm afraid these products are more hype than reality. According to California Custom, the combination of the Aluminum Deoxidizer and Purple Polish are supposed to cut your polishing time in half. They advise that you use the green deoxidizer first, followed by the Purple Metal Polish. They describe the Purple Metal Polish as a, "truly no-rub metal polish". These claims are simply not true! As far as I can tell, the Deoxidizer is little more than a mild cleaner. It does little, if anything, to speed up the polishing process. The Purple Metal Polish works well, but no better than similar products that sell for less than half the price. As far as the "no rub" claim, forget it. You apply and use this product just as you would any other metal polish. In other words, you have to work it into the surface until the top oxide layers are gone. Depending on the original condition of the metal and the shine desired, this may take considerable effort. In fact, if the metal is too far-gone you may have to start with progressively finer grits of wet / dry sand paper. Bottom line, in my opinion, the Aluminum Deoxidizer is a total waste of money and the Purple Metal Polish is no better or worse than any other quality metal polish. It is however, one of the most expensive. Personally, I've had great results with BlueMagic 400 Metal Polish Cream, which currently sells for $4.35. Mothers also makes a good polish at a similar price. BlueMagic 400 Metal Polish Cream - 7 oz. Mothers 05106 Billet Metal Polish - 4 oz
Plug and play? Ummm no. Beyond having to employ my stellar electrical skills to make the connections, it performs as promised.

reviewText: I had a steering wheel puller set (Lisle 45000), but needed a pair of puller legs for removing a steering wheel without threaded holes.  I bought this set to get them, because this set was cheaper than getting the puller legs by themselves. reviewText:
I would not recommend these gloves. Let's pro-con this out.

Pros:
 VERY cool design. That patch of CF on the top, so bling!
 Soft/comfortable material inside and out. If the gloves fit, they should be very nice on your hands.
 The mesh on top looks so cool! Vents well and keeps your hands cool on those summer days.
 The pads on the palms are a nice touch.

Cons:
 Inconsistent fit. My hands are the same size L/R, but the gloves are not? Finger lengths are off, finger widths are off. Q/C Fail.
 The conductive "touch" sensor on the finger tips - no work. I still have to take my glove off to use my GPS/nav, whereas my leather gloves work just fine.
 No finger protection. Like, none. There are these little rubber spots on top of the mid-section of the fingers and finger tips, but what protection does that offer? I would have expected hard CE plastic at the least, or spots of Carbon Fiber (matching the large portion) at this price-tag over the finger-knuckles.
 Last but not least... The mesh. This is the most frustrating part. VELCRO attachment on the wrists which utterly destroys the mesh. First time putting them on shredded it. Then every time after that it KEEPS. GETTING. CAUGHT. IN. THE. VELCRO. Terrible design to put the mesh on the index-finger and thumb. Nothing can be done about it and it looks terrible.

Final thoughts? Save your money, buy a better cloth/textile product glove. Try them out IN THE STORE to make sure things fit and work properly and buy them there. I tried them in a store then bought online.
summary: I would not recommend these gloves

The good and bad:
Voices sound nice and crisp and clear, but music sounds terrible -- no mid to bass range.

reviewText:
The most important part of this product works.  It will inflate your tire.  The power lead is long enough to reach from most cigarette lighters to all of your vehicle's wheels and a little bit beyond.  The motor runs, the pump pumps, air goes in, your tire pressure rises.  All good so far.

It also has a little storage compartment for the power cord and air hose.  Neat!

That's as far as it goes for the pros.

Cons:
Noisy: You won't want to use this at 3am when you're trying not to disturb the neighbors

Cheap/not durable: Not just plastic, CHEAP plastic, flexes a lot, doesn't seem like the casing would survive rough conditions.  Even the cord feels thin and easily sliced or broken

Dim light: Don't even bother with the little red emergency light, dim old-style flashlight bulb, How about a CREE or similar LED.  My LED flash on my phone puts out 10X more light than this does.

Bulky: This isn't the first 12V compressor I've had, it's similar hardware to my last one but twice as big. That plastic case feels at least half empty.  Wasting space in the trunk.

Gauge didn't work right on mine: I probably got a bad one, but the gauge read out works, and the buttons work in some cases, but reset didn't work, auto-shutoff didn't work, and since I couldn't reset the gauge it started at 6.5psi, meaning I had to subtract 6.5psi from the readout as I filled it.  Instead of 32.5psi, I filled it to 39.  It worked, but was annoying.

Slow: Slow, but that's typical with these small emergency inflators.  going from 26.5psi to 32.5psi on a tire on my Dodge Charger took about 4-5 minutes.

Recap; It'll refill your tire.  If you find yourself low on air and needing to boost tire pressure, you'll be glad to have this thing.  99.9% of the rest of the time, you'll be wanting to chuck it in the dumpster.  There are better options out there, I'd keep looking.
summary: Will inflate a tire... if you're not in a hurry.

reviewText:
Let me start off by saying this is not the link I purchased my bags from. The link I had showed the items were being fulfilled by Amazon and sold by powersports. So the box I received was handled by Amazon only so that could of been the issue.

Basically I ordered what I thought was a set and only received one saddlebag. This could of been my ignorance as I had not ordered saddlebags before and not sure if you had to order 1 bag or 2 bags as in if they already came in a set or not.

The description does say "Saddlebags" though giving me a plural word that I assumed meant that ordering 1 meant you got a set of 1 not a single bag.

Also these are slanted bags so they are side specific (You need a specific one for the right and a specific one for the left) But there was no option on the order screen to say whether you wanted a right or left bag. So once again I assumed these came as a set for $142.

Amazon customer service failed to understand my logic as to a right and left sided bag when I asked them how exactly I was supposed to order a set if they only came 1 at a time. Or did I have to just keep ordering them until I got lucky enough to get a left and a right bag.

In the end I just returned the bag. I dealt fully with Amazon on this so I cannot say where the miscommunication was or if the add needs to be tweaked to allow for a left and right side ordering or if Amazon shipping was just careless and only put 1 in the box.

Overall I ordered a large and the one bag I got I was actually upset I did not get the Jumbo because the large was a little smaller than I expected. The bag is nice.. I would warn that this is mostly vinyl so keep sunscreen AWAY FROM IT as I have some saddlemens now and they stain white from my wife's arms
summary: Bad ordering experience, Product looked OK tough

reviewText:
I already own the Torin 6 Ton Jack Stands with the Locking Pin, and the Torin 3 Ton SUV Jack Stands.  Both pairs are great and I use them very often.  I needed another set, and liked the way the locking pin works on the 6 Tons, so I thought I would give these a try.

So why the three star rating?  Well, the pair I received - the pins were not aligned properly making them both a pain to use and moreover unsafe to use.  When I would raise the jack to height, and attempted to slide the pin in, it would not slide without lifting the extension arm with the other hand and "finagling" the pin into position.  Think about that for a minute - typically, I slide the jack underneath the car (which is still being held up by the floor jack), and I then slide the arm up to height, and insert the pin.  Note that I try to get this done quickly as the car is still only floor jack supported.  With these, I would have to find the height, and then have to try and use two hands while lying down under the car to jimmy the pin into alignment with two hands.  I did this once and realized these were not made correctly.  Not sure how these got through QC - then again, seems like lots of things get through "QC" these days....

So why didn't I just exchange them as QC issues happen all the time?  Well, I tried two sets and both sets had pin alignment issues.  Enough for my blood - I just was not one of the lucky ones I guess.  Two for two with issues on both are just plain bad odds.... besides, I am trying not to support companies that allow such blatant QC issues "slip through" for public consumption.  As a result, I probably won't be buying anymore Torin Jack Stands - and take solace in the fact I have two good stands already.  Let's face it - two for two on defective products is more than chance.

Sadly, I was not happy with these - and I really wanted them to work out.
summary: Didn't work out after trying two sets - the pins were not aligned, and would not slide in cleanly - both inconvenient and unsafe

reviewText: Purchased these to replace the wimpy Jeep JK horn. I was terribly disappointed as the horns were not louder at all and sounded more like an old CJ jeep horn. Never have returned an item until now and thankfully the Amazon return process seems easy. If you're looking for loud horns, I'd do more checking around. These just don't make it.

In retrospect I should have spent the extra money for the Icons; since in cold/rainy weather they do not perform all that great.  Once the windshield warms up the rubber they are good at best.  The snap that holds the wiper in has already broke, I should put in a warranty request.

Overall I took a gamble on the price point.  Cheaper materials and quality.

PS:  After trying to email Bosch support, the email comes back as un-deliverable.  I would suggest going with another brand, the days of Bosch quality wipers I guess are over.
summary: Weak & Flimsy - Installed on 2013 Nissan Pathfinder

reviewText: This SP500300 hub did NOT fit my 99 GMC Yukon SLT (even though the part finder says it fits).  The bolts thread *into* the SP500300 hub and the bolts on my 99 need to slide *through* the hub, from the outside.  The correct part that fit my 99 is the SP550307 (and note that the hub is universal (fits driver or passenger side), BUT the clips for the wheel speed sensor fit one side or the other).  It seems most parts places (I called several... including Timken directly) list the SP500300 part incorrectly as fitting the 99 and say that the SP550307 is only for the Denali.
summary: This SP500300 hub did NOT fit a 99 GMC Yukon

reviewText:
I installed one of these on my '02 Maxima a couple of years ago.  Even after bleeding the system perfectly, my car still whines like an old Ford Grenada in parking lots.  I really recommend spending the extra money for the factory Nissan hose instead of trying to save money with this one. This hose does seem to do the job though, and so far my power steering pump hasn't failed, but I can't imagine the noise it's making is good for it.

Update:  The hose has failed about 70k miles and 8 years later.  It's leaking somewhere around where it connects to the pump.  There's a cheaper version out now called Sunsong so I'll buy that one.  I think all of these aftermarket hoses are made in the same Chinese factory anyway.  Oh and the power steering whine never did go away.  Not after 2 more flushes and bleeds.  But considering the factory Nissan hose is still around $200, I'll buy another whiner and save the cash!
summary: These hoses make your power steering pump whine.

Add to that all of the padding - and I can't fit underneath my F150 like on my old creeper.  Even with the truck parked on top of my ramps I have a hard time and can't get past the drive shaft, gas tank or exhaust (so what's the use?).

Add to that - the finish on the metal parts is terrible.  The paint is so rough on the arms that it must have been filthy when it was painted.  If I don't strip it and repaint it - then it will rust quickly.

If you have a 4"+ lifted vehicle and want a large comfortable creeper which you don't mind repainting - then this is what you want.  Otherwise you should pass on it.

reviewText:
I have A 24' fiberglass boat with light oxidation, moderate in some places along with some deeper scratches from dock contact.  I was hoping this might be a professional grade product that when paired with the right pad and a good quality polisher might do a good job of restoring the boat's original shine.  I used a Dewalt 7/9" polisher with a Dewalt semi-flexible backing pad.  Tried several different types of pad, including; smooth foam, ribbed foam and wool bonnets.  At best the result was mediocre with no real improvement evident even on light areas of oxidation.  Rubbing by hand with a Turtlewax cut and polish from Walmart did a better job!

I then changed direction and tried  Meguiar's M6732 Marine/RV One Step Compound - 32 oz.  I had low expectations after the poor result of the expensive 3M product but I have to say that the Maguiars product worked like magic!  After an afternoon with the Dewalt polisher my boat looks brand new!  I was very happy and extremely impressed with the Maguiars product that is half the price of 3M.

I think every situation is different and different manufacturers and eras used different types of gelcoat formulation.  Perhaps the 3M product works well in some applications?  On my Rinker Captiva the 3M product was useless and a waste of money.  At $18 the Maguiars worked like a miracle product.  With a second application and some focused compounding it even took out most of the dock rash.
Did not work. My knock sensors are already sending a DTC code after only a couple thousand miles.

"Strongarm" is the right name for these, as you'll need one to close the glass with two of them installed. They do also really snap the glass up fast, which is nice but also a little too powerful. Like the other reviewer, I think they put too much pressure on the hinges. Also, in the last inch or so of their extension travel, they make a grinding sound just before they reach the fully extended position. Overall quality is questionable, but it might be a you get-what-you-pay-for thing..

I have any older  Bad Boy (not chrome)  which is very loud and sounds good.  I decided to acquire the Chrome Bad Max which is suppose to be louder and better sounding, NOT the case, doesn't  sound like  what is projected on their web site which compares both the Bad Boy and Bad Max.
I am In  the process of returning this horn and purchasing the Kurykin cover for my current horn.

Oh, for those having issues with  loudness, ensure the connections make good contact and the polarity is correct, if the negative and positive connections are reversed the horns won't generate the high dbs.

I purchased one of these fans and ending up returning it for a refund.  It is inefficient and noisy during operation.  The thermostat was useless as I found the only way my fan would cycle on and off was when I turned the heat up far more than necessary or needed it to be.  I found that running my ceiling fan in reverse on low or medium was a thousand percent better in keeping the house evenly heated and I never had to turn the dial past the number "2"..  If you don't have a ceiling fan you can substitute a regular fan but if you use your heater as much as I do it is far better to spend a little more than the $30 you would be spending for this noisy inefficient thermostat blower and install a ceiling fan instead.  I just want to say that these Pro Com heaters are fantastic, they put out a ton of heat, more than you can probably stand!  This heater with a ceiling fan is the perfect combination.  You'll hardly ever need to turn the house heater on depending on your climate, especially if you leave your bedroom doors open and close the doors to the rooms that you don't use that often.
summary: Buy or use a ceiling fan instead!

Use for 2003-2005 honda CR-V.  The tool only engages the very end of the bolt as the handle interferes with the power steering pulley bolt.  So the tool while able to get the belt off...was useless in getting the belt on and rounded the end of the bolt.  The way I recommend you do it, is to have the belt on all pullies except the crank pulley.  The put a 14mm wrench on the tensioner...then take a 1/2" ratchet and fit into the open end of your wrench....now you will have plenty of leverage, good bolt engagement and plenty of clearance.  Slip the belt onto the lower pulley and spin the crank pulley to get it the rest of the way.  I ended up rounding off the teeth on this tool.  Like stated above, I used my own tools snd sent this tool packing.

reviewText: Too small to fit my Lexus ES330 (aka Camry).  Would not stay up with the visors.  Flimsy.

Installed on 2015 Ram 2500 4x4.

Not recommended unless you're a decent mechanic and fabricator.

For starters, the paint is terrible and all pieces had chunks missing from shipping.  Component quality is good but paint is unbelievably terrible.

Second,  this says no drilling. .. that's just not the case.  When mounting the lower brackets to the axle pads,  I had to drill and tap the front bolt holes in the truck and drill out/enlargen holes in the actual kit bracket.  I did not run a bolt through both sides of the bracket as directed,  I instead installed grade 8 bolts on front and reused the brake line retaining bolts on the rear - all got locktite.

So after mock fitting,  drilling,  tapping, etc. I then disassembled and repainted everything before the next day's final installation.

The product is fine but instalation was far from simple or quick as a result of improperly designed and painted brackets.  Firestone needs to fix these failures immediately.

The instructions were worthless.  Literally.

I installed the daystar air bag "cups" for the bottom seats also.  This allows the suspension to still flex off road and allows the truck to be lifted at shop by the frame without tearing up the bags.

The one catch to these Daystar cups is that they are about 1.5" thick by the time the air bag rests completely therefore creating a serious ride height issue (truck was already raked down in the front,  and now this kit made my truck a stink bug).

So I installed a level kit on the front of 2", which sucks but had to happen.

So,  the bags allow me to run about 3K lbs in the back with my slide in camper and the truck rides fine and feels stable considering the payload.
summary: Tons of drilling,  tapping, and painting required.

Update 17 Aug 2015:  Today, I attempt to purchase a USA-Canada map.  The result was incredible.  I paid online by credit card and received an email receipt.  Next, I was instructed to follow a link.  I did this and it updated by GPS. However, I had no map of Canada.  I spent about 2 and a half hours on the phone, and learned in bits and pieces that a purchase takes 4 or 5 days to clear. At that time, I can download the map.  It took a couple more calls, the incompetent people will not pass you on.  You have to hang up on them and call back into the cue.  Anyway, when your payment clears, one is not informed as to when this occurs, you are suppose to be able to update your GPS and the map will appear.  Unfortunately, we are leaving from Canada in two days (we are currently 50 miles from the border).  I would never buy another TomTom product.
I purchased this unit while traveling at a retail store.  We were in a small town in Kansas, and there were a few problems, but it was a small town with minor roads.  I spent more than 3 hours to update the maps and software.  In Austin, TX, I headed out for a shopping center that has been in existence for at least 12 years.  When I put the address in, a 9901 number, it indicated that no address greater than 6600, was acceptable.  There are other problems and short comings  in its use compare to our old Garmin which lost its mind, and cost money to update.  I attempted to use the website for support on the issues I had.  First off, it will not recognize my password.  So, I went to the 'forgot your password' option.  Reset, and thought all is well.  When I attempted an email, I had to re-login, and yes, it would not accept my password.  Sometimes, the website does not recognize the model I have, a Start 50M.  It shows only 3 Start models.  This morning, the website showed a bunch.  I selected my model and proceeded only to be kicked out again on my password.  The several emails that I managed to solicit were mostly automatic.  The one that may have been sent by a person was patronizing.  It merely suggested that I repeat the update process (of 3 hours plus time).  I am headed to a store in Austin for a refund.  I did purchase the extended warranty which may be helpful.  There was one plus, unlike Garmin, the TomTom is mindful of sending you on gravel roads.  As an RV traveler, this is indeed a plus.
summary: Totally dissatisfied with product and level of support.

Serious issues with my 99 4runner (which was perfect prior to this, minus a dead factory tail light converter)

Plugged it in as-is, have not swapped the turn signal wires as other 4runner owners mention... I actually just found their reviews a second ago.  All was well during garage test but the ABS light came on a mile down the road on the maiden voyage.  It went off and stayed off after I turned the car off / on again a few minutes later.

Did 120+ miles towing a popup one way a few hours later without issue, but on the way back approaching a stop I noticed my turn signal indicator was lighting up when I braked.  Turning left from that stop, my ABS light came on.  So this has gone from intermittent to reliably: use left turn signal, initiate ABS light until car is restarted.  Press brake, illuminate turn signal indicator on the dash.

Just threw a P1780 check engine light today and also noticed the [R] light of my gear indicator on the dash was now faintly lighting up when I applied the brake, 4 days/250 miles after installation.  This code is for 'Park/Neutral position switch sensor failure'.  I can't help but think these things are all connected in some way.  The installation was as they suggested in the manual and I inspected everything on both the vehicle and kit when connecting (I was actually pretty impressed with the quality).  No splices or anything, properly grounded.

**** UPDATE 2 HRS AFTER ORIGINAL ****

I removed the necessary trim pieces, pulled up the rear carpet, and popped the panels out to give me access - again.  Nothing was pinched, kinked, exposed/uninsulated/crossing or loose fitting.  Still, I disconnected and reconnected every harness (while inspecting both the vehicle portion and the kit portion) and even went as far as to drill a new ground, sand, check against test light, and hit with a self tapping screw.  The previous ground was also solid, passed the test light, and was the former ground for 54w of led floods on the rear for years.

Same symptoms.  Took a video of what was going on in the rear and it was a christmas tree - brakes and turn signals were causing other lights to faintly glow.  Passenger brake light was out.  Conveniently had yet another new one to replace it with and magically the problem was gone 100%.  Skeptical of my success, I went for a 15 minute problem-free test drive until I was 1/4 mile from home - braked for a stop light and my left turn signal indicator just briefly lit up and occasionally lit up the rest of the way as I braked.  ABS light came on when I actually used the left turn signal, and I'm back to where I was before.  The bulb wasn't out when I looked so I'm guessing it'll follow the same pattern of intermittent issues to constant to CEL when the bulb shorts.

TL;DR: I think the internals of mine are not well.  Wish I could say it was a wiring issue as I'd just fix that myself and be done with it.
summary: Not a good buy for a Toyota 4runner

reviewText: The quality and the practicality of these edge guards is questionable. I bought these because they are supposed to be carbon fiber and they looked good on a black car. In practicality, they can target only a very small area in which to protect your door and I bought these knowing that. I was primarily attracted to the looks. The quality is disappointing to say the least, My first set lasted approx. (1) year before turning completely opaque from what was a very dark black. Admittedly the car sits outside but, I do not live in constantly sunny area. I have just purchased another set and would like to comment on the difficulty in removing the old guards. The only practical way to remove these was to use a heat gun, just to the point to make them pliable, then taking a nylon molding removal tool, like a flat pry bar and work the tool under the guards while hot to remove them from the car door. What remained was the adhesive, which can be removed by using spray clear coat safe adhesive/decal remover. Caution and patience needs to be exercised during this whole process as damage to the paint can easily occur.

This product might not be for everyone.
  The bike:  Before you get this product make sure you can lift your bike over your head and able to step and balance with your bike in your door area. This is how you'll put your bike on the rack. So practice this. You'll have to grab your bike from the very bottom and lift it keeping it balanced above your head. As I put the back on and off the rack it became unbalance and almost busted out my passenger window.
  The installation: Place a blanket or sheet under your crossbars. States to place the loop end on your factory cross bars first facing the front of your vehicle. I found this very obstructing with the other clamp. I would suggest to open both ends all the way and set it down evenly. Once placing it on factory cross bars in the direction stated by Yakima, DO NOT open your 5th door. When you do, you'll notice your 5th door won't open all the way and it will hit it. Be careful, if you open it the rack end will scratch your paint on your back door.
  Contacting Yakima: Yakima suggested to put the rack on backwards. Yes it did fit but, the two loops fly up in the wind while driving. You will need to design a strap to hold them down. Shouldn't have to modify it.
  My Suggestion: If your ok with all of the above, buy it. Not a bad price. If not, stay with the Holdup 2 or other Yakima racks.
summary: Would not reconmed for a GMC Terrain 2013 or 2014

reviewText:
Description makes it sound like each one is 16 watts, where I tested one on a regulated 12V supply and pulled 640ma, which puts it below half of it's claimed wattage.  Held up next to a charged 800lm Nitecore MH2C flashlight, it wasn't quite as bright and had a lot of stray light.  As many of CREE's LEDs exceed 100lpw I'd expect them to be closer with their power consumption, but indeed I couldn't find any CREE LEDs that visually resembled those in these lights.  Reflectors were crooked on both of them, I took one apart to line it back up and it didn't make much difference to the light pattern, though it's not hard to do; six screws hold on the front bezel, another holds the reflector down.  There's a rubber gasket around the lens that fits over a lip in the housing for what appears to be a good seal.

Wires were sleeved and tinned, fed through a tight grommet, and the housing seems sturdy enough, so I guess they've at least got that going for them.
summary: Not quite what they claim to be

They fit in my Hyundai SantA Fe. BARELY.
1) You MUST remove the entire headlight assembly as there is absolutely NO way to replace the bulbs otherwise. A Standard bulb can be maneuvered in place in less than 3 mins.  Good luck getting the assembly removed and reinstalled without scratching the bumper cover..the joining seam for the assembly sits low and behind, so it grabs the back of the bumper cover and pulls it out of place. Fun.
2) You CAN hear the fans inside the car. Not horrible, but I heard them. Oh well.
3) The lighting STINKS. It's white. That's the best I can say. Problem is that there is NO depth to the beam. I do not care what the advertised Lumen rating is..it is significantly less than an Sylvania or OSRAM H7 bulb. I know the aftermarket makers play with the numbers..but this is ridiculous.  The issue is that this bulb is LONG. The actual bulb itself is longer, and the LED lighting element is deeper into the lens ( projector type ). So the focus is WAAAAY off. Tragically short. Without exaggeration, the usable light path is 25 feet.  It is 1/3 of a standard H7 bulb and 1/4 of an HO Off Road bulb. The side-by-side comparison was absolutely pathetic.  The light source is just too far ahead of the reflector and that shortens the focal point dramatically. I almost hit a Bicyclist tonight pulling into my own drive..he was completely in the dark.  I measured the height of the beam cut-off..it's dead-on stock. It just has no brightness..it just fades away to nothing.  So out they come after 2 hours of use ( and 2 hours of install time...) and in go the Osram H7 Off-Road HO bulbs.

Can't return them, I waited a couple weeks for decent weather to do the install...so I'm out of the return window. I won't even give them away, they are just too unsafe to use.
summary: Good luck getting the assembly removed and reinstalled without scratching ...

reviewText:
I was looking for an affordable auto oil filter for my motorcycle. Others have recommended that this filter would be a good replacement for my bike (FJR1300). I beg to differ... The canister is soft and malformed when I went to tighten it - 3/4 of a tun past contact. But the real concern come when I did tighten it. Most filters feel spongy when tightening due to the gasket. This one did not...as It just stopped. I attribute this to a thin gasket. The filter isn't leaking, but I do not feel comfortable using this filter on my bike. A motorcycle rated filter is on order...

UPDATE: This excerpt was taken from the Purolator site: "If you're thinking you want to install a PureONE oil filter on your bike, please think again. PureONE oil filters are designed for vehicles, not bikes. Because of PureONE's high efficiency, the motorcycle oil pump may not be able to handle the pressure. The Purolator motorcycle filter line is designed to meet the specific needs of a bike; therefore we highly recommend the use of a Purolator ML filter over a PureONE oil filter".

reviewText:
I have a 2000 Honda Foreman ES 500, with no modifications to (stock) handlebars. The positive side is the wiring is fine, connects to their LT2000 winch on my setup as expected. That's where the fun stops, here's my negatives...
 A slight negative point, is the big electrical/junction box is very bulky and makes it tricky to find a good hiding/mounting spot. The biggest negative point though, the bar mount is total trash. It spins around the bars any time you push either of the buttons, so you have to hold the button mold still from behind while using it.
 Also, it doesn't always connect or make contact "inside" the switch weatherproofing. If it didn't work at all, i'd drop a star, but it technically works so it BARELY earns that second star. Get a thin piece of tire tube, or some sticky-to-metal material like rubber, to go between the mount and your bars, else it's a major waste of time/money.

I recommend researching other products heavily before choosing this product.
summary: Trash mount setup hurts this as a useful option.

reviewText:
Amazon lists this pump as a factory pump for my 1993 Jeep Cherokee 4.0L, but that is not the case.  This pump required a fair amount of modification to fit because it is significantly smaller.  Fortunately it is not that difficult to fit most in-tank fuel pumps into the Cherokee assembly, but this pump is being sold as an OE fit and that is why i gave it 2 stars.

I ended up cutting the large white plastic adapter almost in half (far right in the picture) and cutting a hole in the rubber of the upper mount of my in-tank assembly for the hose to run through.

I ordered this in a rush and it is working fine, but most of the reviews of this pump on the Jeep forums have a low lifetime expectancy (~2 years).  I would recommend looking elsewhere (avoid Carter and Airtex too).
summary: Works, but not OE fit and i'm unsure it will last.

reviewText: Not as bright as I expected. Although these lights do appear bright looking at them,  the distance the light travels is upsetting.... they are not at all what I expected... returning them is probably what I'm going to do

Folks who are going to use a license plate frame are usually going to have a polycarbonate cover over their license plate too.  Well, not with this frame, you're not.  If you want to put this frame over your plate, you're good to go.  The frame is well stamped and polished, the edges are folded back at a crisp 90 degrees, and there are even tabs on the back side to give extra support to your plate. Overall, I would say it is well constructed.

Now, let's talk about the design.  I have two issues, aside from the frame not fitting over the cover.  First, the spacing of the horizontal mounting holes is 1/16" too close.  I can  push it on, it's tight, but it would work.  The second issue is that the interior portion of the mounting tabs, where the mounting screws go through, are squared off.  Maybe this is just a styling thing, but I prefer that they were rounded.  In my opinion, it just looks more "finished".

So, bottom line, if you are not using a licence plate cover, you'll probably be satisfied with the material and construction.  It's just not well suited to my application, so it'll be relegated to the spare parts bin.

I needed a scanner to diagnose a 2000 Cadillac Catera. Repair shop said they weren't getting "proper" trouble codes. I used this to one, find the problem, and diagnose subsequent issues. This tool was capable of an additional level of communication that $20-$50 scanners couldn't do, but it didn't have the full reach of $1,000 commercial products. If you need such a tool I highly recommend it, but be aware it won't diagnose the problem for you, more like assist you. i also understand some parts stores will hook your car up to their tool for free, so try that first.

I purchased this to replace an identical part number kit that was installed on my vehicle. My (older, but same model/part number) version attached onto the rubber trim around the windows. When I got the old (damaged) stuff off, I realized that the new kit had been restyled even though the part numbers were identical. The new version now sold adheres to the paint around the window trim and so does not come as far down on the window. I could have adhered it to the top edge of the rubber trim, but then the sides would not have matched up. Basically it's not as much of a sun shade as the older version. But it stops rain from coming in the window still, so it's not completely useless.

I liked the old design. Otherwise, the thing is just as durable as the old version.
summary: BEWARE - Not the old style; Otherwise its FINE.

reviewText: The materials a little thin

Background:
These went one some V&H Shortshots on a Harley Davidson Iron 883.  I wrapped the pipes up without the heat shields.

Reasons I did it:
Looks mostly.  I thought it looked damn cool.
Supposed to regulate the heat to slightly increase performance... who knows if it does.
I wanted to run these pipes without the heat shields since the bands snapped and rattled around.

Install:
Not easy with one set of hands.  Find a buddy or a spouse!  This job is so damn hard by yourself and it doesnt look like its possible for it to be done well enough.

Results:
I like the look and the heat seems to dissapiate evenly throughout the pipe now.  Maybe that increases performance? Who knows?

I would suggest you use steel clamps from the old heat shields instead of steel zip ties.

Time will tell how durable they will be.  Lots of compliments even from non-bike folk!
summary: Looks cool...  that might be it.

Product shown in picture is not what I received.  The ignition rotor I received was white in color and came with Phillips type screw fasteners.  The color of the plastic will not affect the operation of the part.  Their was a difference in the new part in comparison to the OEM original GM part that I removed from my vehicle.  The Phillip's screw threads that came with the new ignition rotor were shorter in length and would barely reach to secure the new rotor on the distributor shaft.  I had to use the original hex head screws from the original oem ignition rotor that I was replacing in order to get the oem fitment. This again seems to be a questionable AC Delco quality issue.  The picture representing the part should resemble the part you are purchasing.  Customers make their purchasing decisions based on what they see and read about the product.

reviewText:
We first used this unit on a sunny afternoon while driving in a westerly direction.  We could barely see the display due to reflections on the screen.  We still had our older nuvi 1450 in the car so we put them next to each other.  After checking the brightness setting on both, the 1450 definitely has a brighter display than the 2597.  In fact, by dimming the 1450, we determined that the 2597 display brightness was about 60% of the 1450.  The display background on the 1450 is bright white, where the 2597 has gone to an off-white or light grey with streets highlighted in white.  That seems to add to the display issue.  In most cases, the difference is probably not a problem.  But the 2597 display will have a hard time overcoming sunlight on the screen or reflected light on the screen from inside the vehicle on a bright day.  We had one of those cheap visors from Amazon that helps with direct sunlight.

I still have an ongoing complaint about these units and that's the way it announces and displays upcoming turns.  It may say to turn on 1st Street which in fact may be true in the local jurisdiction you're driving, but in fact is also US41.  1st Street may or may not be identified by a street sign, but US41 definitely will be.  Always good to do your homework to be sure you're turning where you want to, especially if towing.

I don't have any experience with its Bluetooth capability.  I tried traffic one time in an Interstate highway backup but nothing was available.

We bought this item as a Gold Box deal of the day and even with its display shortcomings it was still a decent deal.
summary: Display not as bright as earlier models

reviewText:
Optima used to be one of the top names in batteries. They were a very long-term and reliable solution. However, my last few purchases have been quite disappointing across several different models and cars. I've had three red and yellow top batteries that were either bad upon purchase or failed within a year. I don't think it's just coincidental that Optima changed their warranty...they've changed something and I don't believe they feel the quality of their product is as good as it was.

They're still worth considering, but are no longer a sure thing. You might want to look at other brands, especially those sold by places like Costco that truly stand behind their products.

That being true. The small tube included is for pumping up inflatable toys. It does not include a pump adaptor. Its not in the photo, it doesnt come with one.

This means the small tube being used for anything, changing oil from dip tube on a car for instance cant be done due to lack of adaptor. You cant pump anything with that tube.
Why did the supplier include it intentionally not including a proper adaptor.

The caps on in/out of the pump can be removed and there is a hole it fits into but its not a sealed tube to cap. Thus usless. Don't get oil on the tube caps.
This is worth the price, doesnt do what it claims.
summary: Can change oil on lawn mower, cant pump air to toys or change oil on cars

I bought this cabin air filter replacement for my 2014 Hybrid Camry. The process of changing out the air filter was very easy, it took me only 2 minutes to change out the filter, you can look at the pictures to see the process of changing out the filter. My AC was emitting a weird funky smell, we had the original Toyota air filter on and we're currently at 27,000 miles.

The reason I gave this air filter a 3 stars rating it's because the air filter that I received has only HALF of the folds compared to the original Toyota air filter. The picture shown on the item's page shows the same air filter as the original Toyota air filter but the one I received does not match the picture. Look at the side by side comparison of the air filters. I'm not sure if there are going to be any issues with having only half of the folds. Even though the air filter that I received is different from the original air filter in number of folds, the sizing matched the original air filter. I ran my AC at full blast with the new air filter and there was no more smell.
summary: Similar to the original Toyota air filter but it has only half the amount of folds

reviewText:
If you are looking for a battery charger with desulfation technology, this is not the best choice as the included info lists the desulfation stage as stage 1 of it's 5 stages only, which is from the (near dead battery) zone of 7 to 11.5 volts. Misleading advertising you may think you are getting a battery revitalizer but above 11.5v it's only a charger. Best you don't allow your battery to become discharged that badly anyway as it can shorten it's life. Other brands are available that desulfate 100% of operating time but they cost more, such as B@tteryMinder 1500,1510 (Considering battery prices, I say they would be worth the added cost) and Xtreme XC100-P. If you decide to buy this unit you should monitor it with a voltmeter to make sure that after the initial charge to 14.4 volts it does not drift below 12.5 volts before cycling back into charge mode, because there has been an issue with these allowing batteries in their care to become discharged. It may need to be unplugged briefly to reset before it starts charging again. That's why it can't be trusted as a maintainer. It could likely be a dependable maintainer if it were put on a timer to give it some off time each day, to cause it to reset. In spite of all that, it is a multi-stage, energy efficient and safe machine for charging 12v motorcycle, lawn tractor, car n light truck batteries, whether standard flooded or AGM type. Will not overcharge.

For you DIYers- Build your own maintainer for less that is likely to out-perform this thing since the float mode works when it wants to on these. Buy a 13.5vdc switching adapter (preferably at least 2amp) and connect it to your 12v Lead-acid battery, can be left on indefinitely. Considerations- May need to use a resistor like a 12v, 55watt bulb (or similar) in one output lead to prevent overloading adapter till the charge level rises in battery.  Alternately you can use a 14v adapter and a blocking diode in one output lead between adapter and battery, which will drop it about 0.6v to 13.4, which has the added benefit of eliminating the possibility that any current will ever backfeed to the adapter or discharge the battery if it is unplugged. Both these setups are great for giving a slow, gentle charge to 100%, and extending the life of a battery. You see, a fully charged wet cell 12v battery left idle for long enough to dissipate surface charge will measure about 12.7v. however once it is partly discharged from starting your car, your car's alternator will hold constant voltage around 14.2 or more to bring the charge level up in the short time you drive before it's shut off. But if time is not an issue, constant 13.5v will also bring it up to 100% after a day or 2, without the water losses associated with higher charging voltages. Since this method is both less costly and often more dependable than a commercial unit, I think it's a win-win. Works great. But it does require some assembly.
summary: These don't live up to the hype.

Friend used a T-30 instead of a T-40 on the bolt and stripped it to a circle.  Don't do that.  Top one headache on top of another, the Bolt Extractor broke inside the bolt.  Needless to say, headaches for all involved.

But past that, the Light Bar does what it's supposed to, but don't expect it to be of the best construction for the price.  The Mounting base for the Lights are uneven, one of the mounts were bent lower than the other during the welding process.

reviewText: It may have helped a little but sometimes the rings are just too worne.

The illumination of the screen and of the valve connector is great to have, and the reading seems to be accurate; but the overall shape is awkward to use, and it's hard to get it positioned so that it seals well to the valve, and (for me) it keeps changing from the PSI units I want to BAR units that I don't want -- so with every measurement I have to press the button several times to get it to read in the units I want.

When I received the item I was happy with what I got for the money. I feel that the seller should just ship the item as a kit that the buyer puts together themselves.

When you get the item take it completely apart and throw away that awful hose that looks like it should be nowhere under a hood. Make sure to use the proper tools. I took some extra time to take a file to any burs and rough edges so everything will seal properly. If you can buy one or have a O-Ring kit get one (I purchased a very nice 200+ piece one from harbor freight for under $10). Also you will need some Teflon tape. Remove all the O-Rings and replace them with better thicker ones from your kit. Keep in mind that the connectors on top have no seals on them. The level tube on the side will need some more Teflon tape on the screws and put some on the screws on top because the threads go all the way into the container.

If you take your time and make sure everything is completely sealed you will have yourself a quality oil catch container for a very cheap price.

You don't need to do exactly what I did but what is important is having this container completely sealed because a vaccume leak in your ssystem can cause countless issues depending on your vehicle not to mention you won't be catching oil and possibly causing crank case pressure to build up in your motor and that's a problem you don't want or need.

Take your time and do it rite!
GOOD LUCK!!
summary: Quality Parts, Put Together Sloppy (rebuild yourself)

reviewText:
Installed these on my 2015 Wrangler JKU, and overall they are simply "OK".

Installation was a game of lining up the screws and bolts as loose as possible because the fitment was no where close to ideal. Had 2 of the bolt holes on the bottom of the steps actually come loose with just minor torque when tightening, and wasn't able to fix.

Finish was consistent, no issues with paint chipping. Steps themselves are cheap plastic, not rubber. They look like a good kick would pull them right off the tube rail.

I'm not a fan of how these mount to the pinch seam without any provided rubber paint protection or padding, as over time they will scratch the paint underneath and expose the possibility for rust at the pinch seams.

These did take a decent hit against some rocks offroad, which dented the underside of the tubing (expected) but also dented the front metal fender at the pinch seam (not expected). I'll eventually get these replaced with some true rock rails.
summary: Decent non-offroad steps, but quality needs improvement

-Fit: Front fit great, Rear Cover was HUGE, but I managed with just tucking the excess material away.
-Look: Big Meh, not an improvement for a new car. The fabric with the pattern was more yellow than beige, the headrest and non-pattern fabric portion was beige though.

reviewText:
I'm giving it 3 stars instead of 4, because I can't give it 3.5.

The pot should have come with a regulator for the air side of the gun. I added one and it made night and day difference. Considering the cost of a small regulator, it should have been included with the purchase. The pop off valve is a little iffy as well. It seems to let loose at less pressure than what is claimed in the instructions. I find that running the tank at 10-20 psi is more than sufficient to push single stage enamel. I run the air at the gun at 40 psi. This 1.5 tip seems to like the higher atomizing rate. The tank seals nicely without allot of effort on the wing nuts.

The regulator for the pot pressure seems to work and is fairly close with another regulator I checked for accuracy. I have painted two grain wagons with this pot. I have shot 4 gallons of enamel through it. The 1.5 tip sprays single stage primer and enamel well. The gun has a wide fan. It will hold a gallon bucket of paint inside so you don't get the pot dirty. I can see in the future I will be buying longer hoses, 10 feet is not enough when painting large equipment.

For the money and a few tweaks, this is a good starter pressure pot.
Good shine, but doesn't last
Not the highest quality.

I ordered this to use on an older Mini Cooper along with a roof top cargo carrier (http://www.amazon.com/Cargoloc-32424-15-Cubic-Waterproof-Carrier/dp/B001KW00NY/ref=sr_1_46?s=automotive&ie=UTF8&qid=1433434658&sr=1-46). It arrived without two of the four protective rubber/plastic covers, but Amazon offered  a partial refund if I kept it because they didn't have another currently in stock to replace it. I ordered some thick non-adhesive rubbery shelf liner and cut it to fit. The shelf liner did a better job than the protective covers on my test drive, so I just tossed the covers.  Face it - this is a much less expensive option to the name brand versions and at $58 was the least expensive I could find with Amazon Prime (sold by RADO AUTO), but it did the job for me on my 1400+ mile trip in the middle of some serious rainstorms. It is important to follow the installation advice of placing the feet over the strong supports of your car so tightening it down doesn't cause damage to your roof. My additional advice is to check the straps every 300 miles or so and re-tighten them. I checked mine each time I stopped for gas.
summary: Missing two protective foot covers, but with a substitute for them it worked fine.
