reviewText:
Gave this product 5 stars because in the 10 years that we have used our Yakima roof rack with various accessories and components, nothing has ever been taken, although attempts have been made as evidenced by the screw driver marks on car window frame and gouge marks on locking towers....these locks are a bit overpriced, but they do work well and have weathered exposure to the environment, snow, rain, heat, etc. If you want peace of mind, they're worth it, in fact, we leave the rack on all year long without worry.

UPDATED: Dec 8, 2015...will downgrade to 3 stars because of overpricing pricing, something that didn't really hasn't occurred before until i put into percpective, the relative  of locks vs component one is trying secure. You see, i recently added/upgraded components to roofrack, the Mako Saddles to be used for transporting tandem kayak. Unbelievabe. It turnsout, the Mako Saddles cost less than this lock housing (4ea needed) when combined with euro lock key system (4ea needed). I see this as an insult to ones intelligence. I actually cannablized our other car's  racks to determine where this lock system is not that necessary so that i could minimize having to purchase additional locks, in other words, i essentially cross loaded locks between several complete yakima systems. At this rate. I have grown to dislike yakimas business model and continue to seek alteratives and gladly purchase other brands such as thule when economically appropriate. I hope yakima has this realization. Now that my son is attempting to reintegrate back to the community after a year's combat tour in Afghanistan and needs a roof rack system, i will not recommend yakima system but instead, proactively purchase a brand other than yakima. Yakima quality is great but paying more for locks than the component to be secured is utterly ridiculous. I should have just drilled a couple holes and utilized padlock, this might be "hack" but sensible because paying almost $140 for 4 locks is idiotic; mako saddles costs less. If purchasing Saddles for round bars and would like to integrate these locks, factor in price of adding $130-$140 for 4ea locks.
summary: Excellent deterrent, but sometimes costs more than component needing lock

reviewText: I received the Iwata LPH80-124G (1.2 tip) and it appears to be a genuine Iwata and built well.  I'm relatively new to painting, I own a Devilbiss Tekna for most BC/CC and had bought this to help with door jambs and other tight spaces in the engine bay.  When using it, the instructions and material online indicate that it should be set to 7-14 PSI at the inlet to achieve 10 PSI in the air cap.  This appears odd that the range would allow for less than the required at the air cap since there is generally a fair loss from inlet to cap.  Nonetheless, I set it on the higher end ~14-15 PSI and it doesn't have enough pressure, I had to raise it to over 20 PSI at the inlet.  I am worried that it is too high based on the instructions and would result in dry spray and was in the middle of spraying my car, so did not proceed to use it.  I am not sure It could be that I'm using a 0-140 PSI regulator, so it may not have been precise.  I will eventually try a 0-30 regulator and update accordingly.

You would expect this to cover everything so that the tube is guarded well.  However it seems thin and I noticed that the edge of it felt a little sharp and hard!  That would be all that I need to have happen!  To have what is supposed to protect my tube to actually slice it! I'm glad that I have a another one that I have had since the last time that we had a tire put on this bike because this one just did not seem right to me at all!  I would not use it!

I was looking for some new headlights for my 2004 TJ Rubicon because the old stock halogens just weren't cutting through the pitch black darkness of the rural country roads that I frequent. I saw these as a great upgrade option because of the reviews and I'm a fan of the halo look on Jeeps. They came in and installed extremely easily - essentially just a plug-and-play. Unfortunately, if you're installing these on a TJ (1997-2006), the included fuse tap harness for the halos has to be plugged into the fusebox behind the glovebox in order to get the functionality you're looking for. If you try to plug it into a fuse in the engine bay, the halos will remain on regardless if the key power is on or not. So I cut the wire, passed it through the firewall, and then soldered it back together. I plugged it into the fuse labeled "SPARE" in the owners manual (I can't remember the fuse number) and now the halos function perfectly as DRLs with the key turned on. You'll also need a matching fuse for whichever fuse you choose to tap. The "SPARE" fuse is a 20A if I remember correctly and I had to purchase that separately. The white halos are bright and look clean. These lights also include yellow halos that use another included harness that splices into the turn signal lights but I opted not to install this option after using the headlights. The actual headlights I found are not very bright at all. With the halos and headlights on, it actually looks like the halos are brighter. The beams they produce are uneven, undefined, and somewhat splotchy. The high beams are also poor in that they produce a pattern of three beams slightly above the headlight beams which are not much brighter than the headlights. Also, these lights don't illuminate roads, dirt, foliage, trees, etc. well. They seem to illuminate road paint and road signs very brightly and, when driving in pitch blackness, drowns your vision of the actual road and anything that may be on it. This may be due to the fact that the lights produce more of a bluish light than a white light. After about two weeks, I have determined that my stock headlights actually function better and I may soon switch back. I haven't had any problems so far with leaks or moisture getting in the lenses but I haven't had them very long. I'm giving 3 out of 5 stars because I only paid $106 and everything aside from another fuse was included for installation. They also look great from the third person. But I'd go with something else if you're looking for something brighter and more functional.

Pros: refreshed modern look, easy to install, included wiring.
Cons: lacks brightness, awful beam patterns.
summary: Great for looks, poor for vision.

This is a great device for the price.  But to use it, you need to use it with a recent Land Rover.
Documentation of the device claims compatibility with Range Rover second generation (P38) that carry a BMW engine.
As expected it did not worked with my 1999 Range Rover P38a HSE with 4.6 V8 Bosh/Motronics rover engine (NAS spec.)
Sad as I bought specifically to read the codes on this truck.

I also tested in a Defender 1999 and a Discovery 2 TD5.  In this case the manual claim support for them.
I can say that at least for trucks with a first gen TD5 (P10) it does not work properly.  Some features are supported, some not.
The ones that do not work, return false/incorrect readings.

The tool might work on second gen TD5 (P15 or higher) with the latest NNN ECU, but who knows.
iCarsoft should include the specific models they tested their device with.

So on the TD5 based engine trucks It did not worked properly in the following vehicles:
- 1999 Defender TD5 (P10 engine) with older MSB ECU, Rest of the world spec.
- 1999 Discovery 2 TD5 (P10 engine) with older MSB ECU, Rest of the world spec.

Need to test Disco3/4, Later Range Rovers/Sport and Defender puma, but I know about reports that they work fine with those.

Final comments, hopefully iCarsoft will update their documentation to specify what TD5/ECUs were certified or at least include support for Range Rover P38 with Rover V8 Bosh engine.
summary: Limited support on Range Rover P38 and TD5 trucks

reviewText: My 2013 Honda Accord  4dr 4cyl with 55,000 miles had a bad right rear hub bearing, self diagnosed based upon rear wheel noise which was getting progressively louder and the problem was later confirmed during routine dealer servicing and 4 wheel alignment, accompanied by road test.  I put the Dura International 29512353 rear hub assembly on both rear sides and mechanically they fit perfectly. However upon test driving after hubs installed the VSA Light comes on and stays on, there is no normal power to accelerate: maximum speed about 20 MPH and a air escaping cycling sound from the engine.  I tried to reset the  cars computer with my OBD II & CAN Scan Tool without any success.  I had the car towed to dealer they couldn't get the computer to reset so the hubs were replaced with Honda OEM hubs and the problem was resolved.  Final assessment was the sensor in the "online replacement hubs" was not compatible with the pick-up sensors on my Honda.  Lesson learned, if the part doesn't look EXACTLY like the original keep looking.  Quality part just didn't work for me.
summary: 000 miles had a bad right rear hub bearing

reviewText: I bought this mount from AutoPartPro based on all the good reviews and the great price. The package arrived within a couple of days. Removing the mount is an easy process and a very good video can be found on YouTube easily. At first the new one seemed almost exactly the same with a slightly lower grade aluminum and a slightly different mold but not too far off from the original. As I put it in place I discovered to my horror that it did not fit. The lower bracket bolt holes were an inch away from where they should have been. I compared the parts closer and realized that the rubber mount was on the bracket backwards from the original. The original on my 2007 Mazda 3 2.3L has a slight elbow extension on the rear facing side of the bracket and a straight side facing to the front of the car with the mount coming out the left side toward the engine. You can see in the photo here on Amazon the exact correct orientation of the mount and the bracket. The one I received from AutoPartPro however had the bracket facing the opposite direction. Fortunately, I was able to remove the rubber mount portion by prying the rubber coated metal reinforced claws on the bottom and pounding the mount out with a mallet. At first I thought I'd just replace the mount in the same bracket facing the right direction but found that the bracket was also molded with a slight degree of angle in the opposite direction from the original preventing the engine bolts from fitting as well. So I removed the rubber mount again and put it in the original bracket with the correct degree of angle (toward the engine). To my surprise it still didn't appear to fit. The video I watched did warn (but did not show) that the engine may need to be lifted further in order to fit. I lifted the engine and was able to get the bolts through enough to get the nuts back on. The pressure from tightening the nuts brought the whole thing back together and all was normal again. The part has only been on for a week now, no trouble so far. Since the construction of the item is nearly exact to the original I expect close to the same amount life from it. Replaced the original at 99,500 miles.
summary: May need to be reconfigured to fit

reviewText:
Mixed feeling here. i just needed the upper gaskets as the upper plastic manifold needs removal to change the coils and plugs on the firewall side cylinder bank. I was in process of re-installing the manifold when I opened the box and found only the metal lower gaskets as seen in the picture.
The felpro # indicates both upper and lower were supposed to be included. Frankly i just wanted the upper as needed, but I could only find the complete kit on Amazon. I was desperate to finish as it takes 5 hours for a plug change on the 2008 highlander - if done in driveway without all of Toyota dealership's tools. I drove 30 miles round trip to an Advance Auto who happened to have in si am still atock the Felpro upper gasket only kit.
In process to return to amazon.

First off, the image this is advertised on Amazon with is "Photo-shopped" and offers inaccurate perspective of size. The Stihl MS 170 in the image looks like a pretty tight (good) fit but a MS 170 swims in this boot. I can put my MS 290 with a 20" bar in the boot with room to spare. The boot is huge compared to my MS 171 (same physical size as a MS 170). This was a good attempt by Kolpin to provide a protective saw mount but it misses badly on the proper sizing for what most people will carry on an ATV. I put my MS 290 in it and went out on a trail and observed the mount flexing which will lead to mount failure quite rapidly I assume. Thats all good that it will hold a 290 but all I take on my "quad" as general provision is a MS 171 with a 14" bar for trail maintenance and the occasional small log. When using it for the MS 171 I noted the saw was chafing on the boot because the boot is way to big for the saw...eventually either the boot will rub through or the saws gas tank will develop a hole. With space being at a premium on a quad (ATV) this boot takes up too much space for what it offers. If it were sized appropriately for a small saw I would likely call it awesome but its pretty much a space hog and not worth what it offers in my opinion. Another thing I noted when running with the MS 290 secured in it was my Honda 420 Rancher actually was tilting (listing) on the suspension toward to side where the saw was mounted...that is a bad thing as balance of load is key when riding trails on a quad. I think I'll stay with strapping my saw down to the front rack as I always have and perhaps mount this Kolpin Saw Boot to my trail trailer and give that a try. Disappointed with the boot and the Photo-shopped image that compelled me to buy it. This might be great for a UTV but its not what I call appropriate for an ATV unless a chain saw is the only thing you desire to carry.
summary: Not really what I expected...the Image is doctored to make the boot appear smaller than it really is...this thing is huge.

reviewText:
Yes it fits quite well and folds, and there is no longer any Velcro to damage the seat backing.  But you are still left with the issue of the cover not staying firmly in place, as the bottom is smooth plastic and the fit isn't perfect.

The top is also smooth plastic, and although there are ridges--they are shallow and not sufficiently textured or roughed to prevent many items from sliding around.  There is a small lip around the edge to help contain liquids, although it is not as high as other major competing brands.  The trade-off is that the front cargo hooks are easier to access.

The product is easy to maneuver because it folds and is light weight, but this is because it is simply a thin piece of plastic that is overpriced for what it is.  If used in the configuration as shown in the image, with the 3rd row seats up, it is a bit awkward functionally due to the height differential it creates when tri-folded.

On a side note, it would be nice if they also offered a longer version to cover the 2nd row seats when they are down, providing a protective surface for the entire cargo area.
A close match, but still readily discernible. Hard to apply, and does not stay on unless you spend a lot of time and effort preparing the surface. No quick fix here.

reviewText:
This unit does not have a home security code that can be used so that whenever it is not at the home location a security code is required to access the unit and waypoint.  This is a huge problem in event of theft and I will not recommend that anyone buy it.

I have a slighltly older model Garmin and it does have this feature and I presumed all Garmins had this feature.  This was a big mistake on my part.  I expect more from Garmin and that's why I'm writing this review to warn others!

Too bad Garmin aside from that issue it seems to be a decent device so far.  It would be nice if the fonts could be increased in size for the speed limits and other accessory information that you can display in the corners.  My old unit is easier to read in fact.

~ Kort

reviewText:
I'm using these on a 2005 MINI. I was looking for inexpensive covers and they fit the bill. However, if you have side bolsters on your seats the covers do not fit the seats snugly. Also,the covers will cover any pockets you have on the back of your seats and any back rake adjustment levers and quick release levers that slide the seat forward.

The covers have a thin foam lining so I doubt that they will stand up to a washing once they have gotten dirty.

One more thing, the illustration makes the covers look like they are a solid grey, they are not. The panels on the sides of the front of the seat are solid grey, the center panel is a multi-hued grey lozenge pattern. (The back and sides are a grey stretch material.)

Despite a broken corner on the top, this bin works as promised. I appreciate that the top actually snaps to the bottom to prevent knock over spills. I have other bins where the top simply rests on top and lacks security.

This bin is the new home to my rolls of twine and thin rope. It's too big to store small items and too large to store anything else bigger than my ropes other than maybe my yarn, bungee cords, or ratchet straps. But even those I don't have enough of to justify trying to fill this bin.

My take away advice is clearly understand the size specs of the bin and the size specs of your needs THEN make a choice.
summary: Ok bin that's an in between size

reviewText:
Not impressed so far. Upon opening the box the horns and compressor appear to be used. Small scratches (through paint down to metal) and some small dents in both the compressor and horns. They'll be where I can't see them so at this point it's cosmetic, but it bothers me to get something already beat up. It makes me concerned how they will perform and the longevity. I'll post a sound clip after I unplug my led light bar and plug this in (high capacity relayed circuit that can handle the 20A required by the compressor).

Update: I tested the compressor without the horns and it works just fine. In fact, by itself it was so loud that it startled me. And so much torque it jumped out of my hand. :)

The good news. I connected the horns and they are loud. I upgraded the horns that came with the truck and they measure 106 dBs (louder than the stock horns). Very unscientific measurement, just an iOS app on an iPhone to measure sound loudness. These air horns measured 116 dBs. Noticibly louder. Again, not a scientific measurement. In both cases the horns are pointed away from the phone.

I recently installed this product using a 6.0 case.

Pros= well made, fairly easy to install

Cons/ the  nylock nuts will make you use foul language. The mount puts the gun case pretty high up which makes some trail riding interesting. I did hit a few trees which didn't phase the case or bracket mount. I did modify the case slightly because there is no support for the barrel end of the case, the bracket is just made as a glorified holster of sorts. Hole on upper end of case does not line up with the Koplin 6.0 case, will not be able to use supplied cotter pin.

The biggest problem is it doesn't give enough clearance at the front of the engine so you have to grind off about a 1/4 inch of material about 3 inches long on the aluminum between the two mounting points of the mount. Not a big job but a nuisance. The OEM has a relief in the casting on the mount for clearance. You can use your old OEM as a guide for how much material to remove. The rubber is a bit hard so transmits a bit more vibration but it seems to soften a bit over time so that goes away. Not bad for the price but not great.  I don't think I would buy it again. Go for one like the OEM so you don't have to alter it to get it to fit.

My ATV is a Kawasaki Prairie 2002. I bought the Can-Am 709400406 ATV Left Mirror and it fit perfect into the 3/8" factory threaded hole. So, the description was exactly the same for this one. A 3/8" threaded stem. Only once I received this mirror, it in fact was a smaller stem size with a mounting bracket instead. It still looks like a good product. But this wasn't what I wanted or ordered. I would've rated this a 5 star if it wasn't for the fact that I will now have to return this product since the description AND the picture is wrong. If the picture and description is ever updated, I will edit my review. Until then, it stays a 2.

I will say that the Amazon return is pretty nice. I don't have to pay for the return shipping and UPS will pick it up at my home. So I did bump my rating to a 3 star.

I just found Can-Am 709400523 ATV Mirror and I'm hoping that this is the correct one. It has the same description as this one, but the picture is of the actual mirror and it looks correct. So, I'm going to try a second time.
summary: This is for a smaller Stem & Mounting BRACKET, Not for a 3/8" STEM.

I do a lot of off-roading in Ohio, which means trees.  Trees/rocks like to grab TJ mirrors and exercise the fold-away features.  Alas, sometimes the angle is just wrong and something breaks.

In the last 4 years of off-roading about once a month I've broken 2 OEM mirrors and I believe 2 of these replacments.  On the OEM mirrors I've broken the 'arm' where it goes into the 'door bracket', and I've broken the glass.  On these I've broken one at the same place as the ORMs, and one where the arm attaches to the mirror head.  While these do nor appear to be quite as strong as the OEMs, they are a *lot* less expensive, and I'm not convinced the OEMs wouldn't have broken with what happened to these either.

At around $30 +/- i spend more in gas getting to the trails once than I would if I have to replace a mirror (never yet broken both in one trip - knock on wood).

So they work for me, and when I slide into a tree/rock I'm disappointed if the mirror breaks, but not that bad.

I left a bad review about this gauge years ago but have since deleted it.
The problem I was having was that if left in the glove box for any amount of time it would sometimes be dead when I came to use it and I would have to replace the battery. I'm not sure why it did this but it could have been getting pushed up against something in the glove box and getting repeatedly activated. It would be nice if it came with a little plastic case that would prevent this type of thing from happening but other than that it works fine and is accurate.
You do have to be a little careful when pressing it against the valve to prevent leakage but I have found that it is a matter of technique. I hold the valve stem with one hand to keep it steady while pushing firmly with my other thumb against the built in thumb rest that is part of the units design. If I feel that there is going to be any leakage (usually caused by not centering it on the valve accurately) I immediately pull it away and retry. Most tire gauges can have the same problem, it's just the nature of the beast.
Some wheels are more tricky than others depending on how much valve stem is sticking out.

reviewText:
(On a 2014 Subaru Outback): This is the kind of neoprene that has the normal, fabric-covered side and the more rubbery surface on the other. This is very good as the cover will not slide around and move easily on my leather seats.
It rolls up nicely and gets stored under the driver's seat in seconds and I don't even bother anymore to use the elastic loops included (as they got stretched out quickly -probably from Summer heat in the car). The stitching (as little as there is) is straight and well done. I could do away with the printed graphics in lieu of embroidery (for the price).
I was concerned about how the neoprene would react against my brown leather and was very careful in using it for incrementally longer periods of time, including at high temperatures and always with leather cleaner and conditioner at hand. Although I did not (and will not) leave it on the seat mid-summer, I put it on and used it while the car was very hot under the summer sun with no ill effects. I have no reason to believe it would damage the seats if left on, but why take the chance?!

I was tempted to mention pricing as a negative. Neoprene is not that expensive and this piece involves very limited labor in the way of stitching. However, I feel this will last quite a while, making it worth for me and -understandably- a low repeat revenue stream for the vendor.

The only negative aspect I had to fix involves the "shoulders". While the rest of the cover sits nice and flat against the seat, the shoulders will quickly flop forward under their own weight. Quicker (like 5 minutes) once/if the neoprene is warm. I ended up stitching a strip of nylon strap with velcro to hold the shoulders behind the seat.
summary: Well worth the price and useful as heck! Particularly good with leather seats -no more towels sliding around!

Once on these mirrors remained snug and in place for 14 hours of driving with no problems.  The mirrors have a snug adjustment, but that's a good thing becuase they don't bounce around very much while going down the road.  Some towing mirrors really vibrate while you're traveling and that can be pretty annoying after awhile.

There are 4 peices to each mirror.  The mirror itself, the wedge bar to hold the mirror in place, and the bolt that applies pressure to the wedge to make sure the mirror doesn't move while driving down the road.  There's also a peice of stick on felt for the wedge bar so it doesn't rub your mirror.

I had 2 problems with the design.

1) The set srew that you turn to apply presure and hold the mirror in place was fine on the one mirror, but on the other mirror there was some much resistance when turning it that I thought I was going to snap the turn handle off.  After several slow attempts with some WD40 applied, it finally turned all the way in.  After a couple of installations the bolt has loosened a little and seems to be fine now.
2) Wedge bar felt strip requires trimming, so it isn't cut to fit out of the box.  While this is a minor thing, it's still kind of a pain.  The other problem is that the wedge bar is loose when the mirrors aren't in use, so if you aren't careful you could loose the wedge and then the mirror would be useless.  The bolts stay in just fine due to friction, but I don't like having loose unattached peices on something like this becasue it never fails that at some point one of them will go missing and will probably happen while on the road.

Overall these mirrors work well, I just wish they were designed a little differently.
summary: Did the job, but the products not perfect

reviewText: Package arrived in a timely manner and in good condition.  Part fit like a glove and was easy to install on my wife's 2006 Toyota Matrix.  When ordering the fender liner please make sure that you have all of the appropriate fasteners.  There are grommets, I ordered (PT Auto Warehouse CPA144-15 - 15pcs per Pack, Fender Liner Grommet; Replaces OE #: 90189-06157), which fit very well.  You do not need 15, it just came in that package size.  There are also push in retainer pins, I ordered (Toyota Fender Push in Retainer Qty: 15 Gripper Box # 20045T), which were a little small in diameter and a little short in length, but they worked (but feel a little loose).  I will keep an eye on them, and if they work themselves out I will replace them with something different. Again you do not need 15 retainer pins, it just came in that package size.  When the inner fender liner came off, we also lost the front bumper extension mounting bracket (Toyota Part # 52114 A), which connects to the very front of the fender liner.  I did not realize this until I started to install the new fender liner.  I recommend that you fully inspect all connection points and make sure you have all the appropriate hardware.  We replaced the right-hand side, I should have given a closer inspection to the left-hand side, as a reference, prior to ordering all parts. Once you get your car jacked up and the wheel off, there are no major special tools needed.  A 10 mm wrench for one bolt, and if you need to remove some retainer pins a flat head screw driver, is all you need.  There is a tool that makes removing the retainer pins easier, but it is not necessary.
summary: Easy to install, Fits well on 2006 Toyota Matrix

reviewText:
I live in Southern California, and water conservation is a big issue. I love to keep my dark-colored car clean and shiny. Most of the gunk/stuff that builds up on my car is light dust. Every other week, the car builds up with a generous layer of dust. Instead of washing with a bucket and water, I get myself 2x microfiber towels as per their instruction, and wash away. First off, great smell, I love using Meguiars products. Secondly, the wax is prevalent in this bottle, it leaves a nice and smooth coat that your finger just glides over.

I was hesitant that it might micro-scratch my paint, but so far, none that I can see. Again, this MIGHT be the wax filling it in, I will change my review if this is true. I always spray on a generous amount of the product so that it lubricates the dust and decrease chances of scratching the paint. With light pressure, I lightly go over the dust to pick up as much material onto the microfiber. It usually leaves enough lubrication on the paint so that I can take my other microfiber and buff it off.

Recently, there was a spell of rain, and it washed away most of the heavy dust, leaving only light dust. I took this chance to use the Wash and Wax to wipe away the excess dust, making my car the nicest looking car on the road after the rain.

Pros and Cons of this polisher.  Best price is Amazon for this product. AutoZone's price is $28.00 OUCH! On complex wheels with lots of different openings or depths such as Hallibrand Vintage wheels, this works really well compared to the time to do by hand. Let the drill do the work and it shines polished wheels very well. Also shines polished aluminum sheets really well. You still have to remove the dirty polish by hand.  The biggest hassle is cleaning it when done. Remember the old Mothers TV videos on this polisher? They never showed you how dirty it gets and having to clean them.  It gets very dirty. Using a dish detergent and water works well but messy either way. Use the extension arm provided to prevent possible contact with the drill end and your wheel. It also provides better control and access to openings in the wheel.
summary: Best prices at Amazon. Highest prices at  AutoZone. Don't buy it there!

The lack of a 5th star is because of the lack of instructions, which would have been nice.  I finally got it going on an old Windows 7 32-bit machine. The driver will not install on a 64 bit machine.  At first, the antivirus said it detected a virus from the driver installation and it removed a file.  As a result, when I tried to connect to my Corolla, I got nothing but cable connection errors.  After quite a bit of internet research, I learned that a lot of antivirus products will flag the cable driver file (.dll file) as a virus, and without this file, the software will not find the cable.  Many posts have stated this is a false positive.  With that in mind, I turned off the antivirus, reinstalled the driver, and lo and behold... I finally connected to the car.  I was able to turn off the stupid and annoying seat belt beeps, although you can't turn off the light on the dash.  I also did some other custom changes and all of them worked.  You can also add an OEM remote and transponder key, although I haven't done that.  In all, it was definitely worth the $20.  Now some tips:
1.  First connect the cable to the PC, then open the techstream program, connect the OBD end to the car, turn the key to ignition without turning on the car, and click to connect the vehicle.  At least that's the way I did it and it worked.
2.  If you're worried that your antivirus says it detected a virus, it's up to you to decide if you move on.  I turned off the AV to install the driver, and I haven't had any problems changing vehicle settings, so I'd say it's indeed a false positive.
3.  Some comments say it'll only work on XP, but for me it worked on Win 7, although it does need to be 32 bit.  There are workarounds online to make it work with 64 bit, but most of them say to extract the contents of the driver program with WinRar.  My CD did not have the files zipped, so I couldn't extract anything.  At any rate, it's working.  Sure beats the hassle and cost of going to the dealer to change some of this stuff.  And actually, they might even refuse to change some of it due to "safety" reasons, like the seat belt chime.

reviewText:
I wear a size 8-9. I bought a size bigger because I wear boots and was thinking their sizing compensation was for shoes not military type boots. That was a mistake. I got the 10-11 and they are too big even for my boots. As a result, I melted the inside heal against the exhaust. If I had the right size maybe they would not have been hanging over so much off my footboards. My next pair will be the right size.

The quality seamed a little less than par but they held up well for the hand full of times I used them before I melted them. I would not be surprised if they didn't last long even if they didn't melt. Not lasting long may be a matter of interpretation because I will only wear them a few times a month at the most. But, at a little over $10 I don't mind buying another pair and I got them in the mail from across the pod a lot sooner then they said.

Other than that, they worked very well. They were easy to put on and take off. They didn't slip on the wet ground while I was stopped at a light. I roll them up in my rain suit and the whole thing does not take up much space in my saddle bag.

I chose this blade because of the teflon material.  I have bought the blade at an auto parts store, previously.  It lasted about a year before I needed to change it.  When the time came for a new one, I opted for Amazon.  The blade was shipped in an appropriate tube and I didn't need to change the hardware out to fit my wiper arm.  The fit on the arm end is snug and one must listen for the click of the tab that locks it in place.
I want to give this 5 stars, but this particular blade arrived slightly damaged.  One end of the wiping area didn't seem to mold properly during manufacture and there's a bit of peel-back going on for the bottom two inches.  Since it hasn't affected the performance and doesn't appear to be spreading yet, I'm not too worried about it at this time.  If it gets worse, I will update this review.

reviewText: I have always used real chamois, but thought I would try these synthetic ones out.  They absorb more water than a traditional chamois and ring out just as easy if not easier.  The one negative is they don't seem to pull water off the surface quite as well as a real chamois.  My light colored paint looked fine, but some of the windows had tiny spots on them where the chamois didn't quite get them completely dry...... even though they were well wrung out when I went over the windows.  Maybe this will improve with use.  Overall they do a good job for the price and you get two of them.  For the painted surfaces, you don't have to wring them out as often since they absorb more water.
summary: Almost as good as a real chamois

reviewText:
Solid design. No worries about breaking or letting loose. I mounted the male bracket such that the prongs were just about flush with the end of my rails  so the end faces of the rail and corner post were touching when mounted.

Best thing is to get the scrap end of the board you cut and screw the bracket to it for a few test fits. I used 1.5 inch wood screws for the rails to secure the male bracket and 2 inch for the female bracket mounted to my 4x4 corner posts.

These are currently supporting my king pillow top mattress and 2x12" frame rail bed. No concerns with strength. I'm ordering again for my next Cal king custom build.

Only gripe is the offset for the male bracket claws is not much, which makes it tricky to get the brackets hooked together; so have a second person handy when it comes time to mount the rails.

All in all, good to go.
summary: Solid and strong. Gets the job done but besure to test fit!

reviewText: Very good quality, fits perfectly on my 2011 next generation KLR 650, simple to install, the only reason I did not give this 5 stars is that the rubber peg is about half the girth of the stock peg which at first was a bit annoying but I did get use to it, FYI, plenty of room between the lever and the engine housing!

I really liked it. Easy to program and easy to use, I have no problems or complaints about this product.

These have appropriate mass and strength and are a good size for standard truck and trailer wheels (my application), and would probably work fine with auto wheels that have adequate clearance in their wheel-wells.  I took advantage of the eyelet to add a 3ft poly rope and wooden handle, which makes these easier to use.  The rubber compound sticks well to both rough and smooth surfaces.

I dropped this a star to 4 since I discovered they can be damaged.  In my case the chock was driven over because the driver forgot/didn't know the chock was in place, and it was squashed (rubber cracked thru on all corners), making it unsafe for further use.  This may be unfair, but I just wanted to make the point that they aren't indestructible.

You'll want at least a pair of these... price is for one.

Note:  These have a strong rubber odor which you might not want inside a living space.  It may dissipate with time, I don't know.  This isn't an issue for my use so I didn't mark down for this.

Note: I only use this product on watch cases, so I can only comment on my experience with it in that application.

First off, do not use it on any brushed or matte finishes, I have never done it but I imagine it would ruin the case. But if you have a polished case it is a miracle product. It removes super fine scratches so easily, and I actually have taken out fairly deep scratches with it successfully.

I dropped my favorite watch and put a series of marks in the case from the fall. Some people say stuff like this adds character, but in this case it just looked awful. It took hours, but I was able to get it out entirely, but even under the brightest light you cannot see anything...looks brand new. I just went very slowly and carefully, and it worked the marks completely out. I will say though, you are going to need patience (or OCD) because it might take a while for more major issues like this.

In short, these are super handy for watch case clean-up. And I would highly recommend as long as you follow the directions.

Update 6/20/2013 - When I connected the tool to PC recently, it has downloaded firmware and program upgrade. It took 5-10 min to finish but everything went well. I am impressed this is much better than my prior experience with another Innova scanner.

I have mixed feeling about Free Repair Solutions website. Whatever is available there is of some value but it is really trying to subscribe you to the premium Paid services. This is the new tool. I had 3160 for over 2 years and this one provides more functions and, what is even more important, covers more brands in OBD, ABS and body categories.
Works very well on a few vihicles I tried it on.
It is very easy to use similar to other Innova products but has more features and gets you better data especially with PC based module.
I have never had a reason to use software supplied with 3160. The software supplied with this product is actually useful. It is browser based but the data and the program runs on your computer. Not only it will print a report that you can hand to a customer but it will store the data for future retrieval.  The scanner/software will pull Vehicle ID and some other information from the vehicle computer automatically so that you can follow up on recalls and such

Now why I do not give it 5 stars:
1. It does not cover Nissan in ABS and manufacturer specific codes. This is a very popular make and it is a shame not to include its diagnostic codes. Nobody else has German makes so cannot complain about those.
2. The software on the scanner and PC claimed to be easy to update, however my experience with 3160 is that the company never supplies any updates. You will have whatever you bought. In 2 years I owned 3160 it had few upgrades but I have never been able to upgrade my unit.
The only way to upgrade is thru PC based Innova program and in 2 years I tried, it always responded "you have the latest version" - what a bunch of xxxx.
Also there is no stand alone "upgrade" installation program to install an upgrade on the scanner if you can get the latest software elsewhere.

reviewText:
I must say, I hate to take off a star of a high quality set of bars, but I must. The photo copy looked like it went through a washing machine. The sentences just run on and on, with no breaks making you read it multiple times.

You MUST refer to the grainy pictures and stare at them a long time to figure which is which. None of the parts are marked. After all that, I looked at the bars and said "Wow, totally worth it!" They look awesome and are very strong.

I have done brakes, ball joints, control arms, tune ups etc, but since I'm not a mechanic, I need CLEAR easy to follow instructions. These instructions only make sense after you fumble with it, dry fitting and guessing a lot.

If these were as easy to install as the nerf bars I put on my F-150 then yes, 5 Stars.  If they at least had a link to download a clear copy of the instructions, then yes, 5 stars. I have to take away a star since they could at least include a CLEAR photo copy. And yes, they do look as good as they do in the photos.
summary: Excellent Nerf Bars, Grainy hard to follow instructions

reviewText: So far so good. I used this sealer close to Trust My Mechanic instructions (you tube). I did drain and flush cooling system several times before use of sealer. All antifreeze flushed out of system. I drained system by removing hose at bottom of radiator. Also I removed threaded drain plug on block each time I flushed. I added sealer after mix with water in 1 gallon jug. Half was put in to radiator the rest was put into thermostat opening. Thermostat was replaced and used during the 500 mile run in. Radiator was filled to the top before car started. Heater was turned on wide open for first 50 miles. I only have 250 miles on car so far but the internal leak has stopped. I have not added any water to cooling system after the addition of sealer. Water lever is good in overflow tank. Car is not over heating. The plan is to put 500 miles total on the car then drain cooling system and put in antifreeze 50/50. I hope it works. Check out Trust My Mechanic instructions on you tube. He has a high success rate with this product. Good luck.

The reason the gent with the Jaguar is upset is because the thread per inch count was not included in the description of this product, he relied on someone else to tell him what thread form his lugs were, and he did not check the thread form with a thread gauge himself.
While 1/2-20 is the standard lug size in America, other countries (England, Japan, Etc.) have switched over
to metric, and in some cases (older English vehicles) may be using Whitworth; who knows???
Saying a thread size is 1/2" is like saying all 6 foot tall people have black hair.
Threads run from fine to course (fine having more torque strength and course having less).
My explanation is simplified as this should suffice for the subject at hand, but I could get into thread form formulas which would put you to sleep (kinda like programming).
IF YOU ARE NOT SURE OF THE THREAD COUNT, GO GET A THREAD GAUGE FROM YOUR LOCAL AUTO SUPPLY, OR ORDER IT FROM AMAZON; THEY ARE CHEAP AND YOU WILL USE IT MANY, MANY TIMES IN YOUR LIFE.
Got two sets and have installed them on my two car trailers (7K and 10K) with no problems. They have a looser fit than the nuts that came off, but torque down just fine.
summary: No such thing as 1/2" thread size! (IT IS: 1/2-20)

I was quoted by the dealership $2500 to replace the driver side seat heaters and the two temp gauges ( interior, exterior) and three blend door actuators. Thanks to YouTube and forums for instructions, & Amazon for parts. I fixed almost all of it for $300 and part of a weekend

The low-side valve on my 2006 Toyota 4Runner was leaking so I thought I would tackle the job myself.  Im no AC guy, so I didn't know a JRA valve from a 8mm standard valve from a hole in the ground.  I wasn't sure what my vehicle had, so I just bought an assortment of valves and this tool and hoped for the best.

I don't even need to tell you the punch line, do I?  Come to find out, my low-side valve is a JRA valve (which I think is also called a high-flow Schrader valve) which is too big to fit through this tool.  I read other reviews that say the Mastercool 5831 model does work with JRA valves (its $30 more) so I ordered that (thank you Amazon same-day delivery!) and it worked like a champ.  Basically, the 81490 kit will work for the skinny valve cores, but not the fat valve cores.

Im not going to fault the tool because of my ignorance on the subject of car AC repair.  Its well built and Im sure would have no problems installing valves for which it was designed.  I did not use the tool, but its all metal construction and built just as well as the Model 58531 which worked great.

Unsure what you have and don't want to make the same mistake I did?  I guess you could just buy the 5831 kit and know that it handles all types of valves.  If you don't want to spend any more money than you need to, make sure you buy the right tool for your type of valve:  I found that polarbearinc.com/Webstore/index.cfm?fuseaction=category.display&category_ID=80 has pretty good descriptions of the various types of valve cores that are out there.

If your research tells you that this tool will fill your needs, I think youll be happy with it.
summary: Good tool, but not for JRA valve cores

reviewText: I leave my old BMW airhead parked on the streets of San Francisco year round, and try to keep it covered most of the time. Even though the weather is better for motorcycle riding for most of the year than much of the U.S., my city's fog and breeziness means dust and grime can accumulate pretty quick. And I'd rather have the UV in sunlight tearing wearing down a cover than the much more expensive vinyl seat and paint job. I selected this Nelson-Rigg XL All-Season cover when it came time to replace my previous cover, which was finally tearing after seven or eight years. Two things I learned that might inform others making a similar purchase. The first point might be of interest to any buyer; the second only to those riding BMW airheads, which have a particularly long wheelbase. First, the cover I was previously replacing a Dowco cover (something like this), which is a substantially thicker material. The Dowco being replaced was probably a bit bigger than the Nelson-Rigg (the equivalent of an XXL), and weighed 2.98lbs, whereas the Nelson-Rigg weighs 1.76lbs. The thinner fabric will almost certainly mean a shorter lifetime, so the fact that this is a cheaper product might still not make it such a bargain. So if you're using this cover where it will still be somewhat protected -- under a carport, for example -- then this might not matter, but if the cover is bearing the brunt of sun and storm, the heavier Dowco might be a better choice. Note that otherwise, the two designs are almost identical; the Dowco has more room above the tail (for tail cases or sissy bars, for example), while the Nelson-Rigg has a second pair of grommets on the skirt, along with attached bungee cords, for securing the cover. Second, the XL is big enough to fit a BMW R100RT -- barely. My bike is a 1988 vintage, but all the late airhead RTs should be about the same size. The primary thing that makes this a tight fit is the windscreen, which is tall enough to keep the skirt of the cover farther up the wheels than I would have preferred. My bike does *not* have a tail case, which would definitely push the requirement into the XXL size. In addition, many old airheads will have the original windscreen replaced by now, so if a shorter windscreen has been installed, the XL might be perfectly adequate. If in doubt, anyone covering a BMW with a windscreen should probably err on the side of caution and get the XXL. Update: Gonna use this on the street in a city? Get some stencils and spray paint and figure out how to mark it as yours. Someone apparently decided last night that their motorcycle needed my cover more than mine did.
summary: Good design; material a bit thin

reviewText:
Not quite the quality you would expect, but it works! They don't call this thing a broom for no reason. DO NOT give this to your wife and tell her to clean the kitchen with it, that's a no-no and may get you slapped.. You've been warned.

It's made of aluminum or at least a cheap metal. So if you go outside and start going ape-sh@# on your car with it, it's definitely going to bend/break. The pole that screws into the broom part is made of plastic, the broom part that the metal pole screws into is also plastic. MOST people that have a general understanding of how to work/handle plastic, this SHOULD last you for many season to come. The ones that do not (most of the negative reviews) will have you believe this thing is a real piece of poopoo.

Some advice for the inexperienced plastic handlers, How-to guide:

Applying your body weight or any kind of excessive pressure upon the "broom" end of Snow Broom could cause the plastic connections between the broom and aluminum handle to snap, crackle and/or pop.

Plastic, that screws into plastic is still "plastic" and requires proper "certifications" when handling up to and including; Excessive force may cause plastic to crack.

Aluminum is a soft metal designed for lightweight use and applying ones own body weight and/or excessive "ape-sh@#" techniques or behavior may result in aluminum weakening at certain points of forging weakness and cause bending.

Should you require additional means of handling such products, I recommend the tube university for all your educational instructions.
summary: True and honest opinion from a consumer as well as how-to guide when using the Snow Joe Broom

reviewText: Great product

The product works wonderfully. I used it to keep the weather seals on my Audi fresh, as they were beginning to make squeaking sounds around the doors. It applies easily and neatly and has been holding up for weeks now through rain and snow. The squeaks disappeared right away and they have yet to return.

However, be careful when applying it! As I was going around one of the corners of my rear door's trim, the sponge applicator got caught on the hinge, popping the cap right off the bottle (with very little force). About half of the liquid spilled onto my beige floor mat. I immediately soaked up the liquid and rinsed the mat as best as I could. However, about a week later I noticed that the fabric trim on the edges of the floor mat became bleached and discolored where the liquid came in contact with it. I can't hold this against the product, because it was my own fault for not being careful enough. Just a warning to anyone who may use it in the future..

reviewText:
This matches the SRC front bumper nicely and isn't that bad to install despite reading other reviews. Sure, not all of the holes lined up perfectly but two minutes with a half inch drill bit fixed that. As for drilling holes in the crossmember and installing with the supplied hardware, THE GAS TANK DOES NOT NEED TO BE DROPPED. It is a bit tight on the drivers side but I was able to get the hardware in place using angled needle nose vice grips and tighten it using about 18 inches of extensions. The passenger side is easy, you can fit your whole hand where the bolts need to be. I did the whole thing by myself in a few hours including removal of the factory bumper.

Another thing worth noting is this bumper will not affect your spare tire at all, meaning it sits level with the rear crossmember just like the factory bumper. I looked online before purchasing but could not find this info. I know some similar designed bumpers sit higher, which would have caused clearance issues with my spare. With the Smittybilt it is a non issue. Great bumper

Excellent product.  I have recently purchased a digital pressure gauge, but this one will check the inside duelly wheel pressure and others won't.  Not every gauge tip has the right angle and small enough profile to check this stems that are angled away from you on the outer tires.  P.I Auto Store emailed me to make sure I was happy.  I was not planning on contacting them.  The gauge wand had slipped reading 20 pounds at Zero pressure, but is still very usable. They sent me another one for free.  You cannot lose with this vender.  If you do have duelly wheels, I have read that 3-5 pounds less pressure on the inside wheel is the best because of the shape of the road.  The most important thing is to be able to easily check the pressures so it can be done on a frequent basis to avoid blow out when tire heats up because there is not enough air to absorb the heat generated.  I also think it is great not to worry about batteries in the digital gauge.
summary: The absolute best gauge for my Duelly wheels at any price, no batteries required.

I purchased this item to split the factory OBDII port so I could run concurrently an installed engine monitoring tool that I added to my truck and the insurance monitoring device which previously was the sole occupant of the port.  The company that provided the engine monitoring tool stated that a OBDII splitter could fail to perform the desired goal of having two devices working concurrently depending on which device loads first at engine startup and how it interacts with the other device.  At this point, my engine monitoring tool appears to be primary as it still fully functions after startup.  I am waiting to hear from the insurance company if they detect that the installed monitor is not reporting anymore (indicating a device conflict the engine monitor and the insurance monitor).  If I don't get a "failure" report from the insurance company in two weeks, I will have successfully installed two OBDII devices using this splitter. [Edit]  The engine monitoring tool worked fine but the insurance monitoring device failed to work when installed on the splitter with the engine monitoring tool.  I returned the Y splitter as it didn't help me have two operable devices installed at the same time on the OBDII port.  It may work in a situation where you have two devices installed but only one operable at a time so as not be conflict with the other installed device.

The splitter is of very sturdy construction using heavy duty wiring.  It sticks out about three inches before the wiring is flexible enough to start bending in another direction.  This could be a problem for you depending on where your OBDII port is located.
summary: Heavy Duty Splitter for adding OBDII devices

Installed most of this set earlier today, it's a very complete gasket set and I was torn between it and Honda OEM. So many people swear by using only OEM but when I needed to do the job myself, I had to ask myself why? It's my daughter's car, 160k miles and it's on at least it's second head gasket, if only 2 then that means the OEM gasket lasted for 80k miles. That's just not super impressive to me, I've had cars older, with more miles that haven't needed a head gasket and I've always liked fel-pro gaskets so figured I'll give it a go. I'll report back if the car has any issues with any of the gaskets in this kit but I am not expecting to have any issues. Thanks fel-pro for making quality, affordable gaskets to keep our cars running longer.

Edit 10-2017

Cars still fine, maybe 15k miles since replaced all the gaskets and everything's working as it should.

However, I received notification a day before it arrived, so it was a Sunday purchase that I received on the following Wednesday, not bad for such a bulky item.  My tank is OEM as far as I can tell, and it has a plastic baffle box for the pump and sending unit that cost me a tow bill when the idiot who changed out the pump just before I bought the pickup had not fastened properly.  It was held in place by a friction washer on a metal post fastened to the tank bottom.  The box had loosened enough to break the pump loose.  Anyway, this tank has a metal baffle box that is spot welded to the bottom of the tank, so hopefully this is a better design, it should outlast the truck.  The shipping box looked like it had been dragged through a war zone, but the tank inside was in great shape.  Made in Canada, for those who are interested.

reviewText:
Settled on these bulbs after much research. What arrived at my doorstop was an unboxing experience! A tight-fit box lifts up to reveal a lovely cover photo, followed by a detailed manual, and finally the well-packaged bulbs which are exactly as pictured. For this price, I expected a plastic baggie, but that honor was reserved for the included hex key and silica packet.

Design is (supposedly) efficient enough that it doesn't require a noisy fan. Body is all-aluminum, in-line connector is waterproof and all wires are in one cable. The aforementioned connector has arrows indicating the correct way to fit the plug.

While I can't say whether these are truly LUMILED, the LED placement matches the original halogen filament well, as pictured. Installation was easy and, when lit, the output is a bright white which just looks great. LEDs shipped already oriented to correctly face left-to-right when installed in housing. Initially I am thoroughly impressed, but only time will tell if this opinion stands.

Cons include the one of the set screws for the chuck getting stripped. No set screws for heat sink included like in the manual, but powdered sealant on the threads seems to be the maker's replacement. OEM connector blades had to be pinched slightly to fit the car, but that's simple enough.

Most disappointing is the warranty. Manual claims 12-months but there is no manufacturer information inside or on the box. This is probably so companies can brand this as their own at a markup and provide their own warranty, such as Rigidhorse for $69.99. With perhaps the best design on the market, it'd be nice to have the manufacturer stand behind their excellent product. For now, Marsons Electronics has provided an unbeatable price!

I was a bit skeptical that such a deal could be had so reasonably ...but so far i am very pleased... both the rotors and the pads are working just fine.. I notice no flutter in the rotors nor fade in the pads... I bedded the pads and rotors as instructed.. and have been using them hard ever since in my '04 TL Supercharged V-6.. I've taken them to almost a stop from well into the triples... and all is fine and dandy.. confidence is steadily building... it's a shame the rotors are from china.. my only real concern... but as long as the quality is there.. then it's too bad an american company can't offer a product as good nor as reasonably priced....I will update as mileage increases.. and pads wear.. I normally am a centric 'stop-tech' rotor and 'hawk' brake pad guy... but this package has proved comparable thus far... and the rotors are still looking good after several months of rolling around dodge... so I will recommend them...

after about 10,ooo miles.. dusting is still average.. brake pedal feel is soft but grippy... there is some brake travel before the brakes find the sweet spot and apply holding power to the rotors... there is a slight bit of rotor whir while braking... once heated up.. the brakes inspire confidence and spirited application... that does increase dusting further...into the low end of the moderate to heavy zone.. there is no rotor flutter or warping noted at this time.
summary: So far working and looking great

I must say I did quite a bit of research on this unit when it came out but the price had me stray away from it.  Last week I happened to be looking at the scangaue and I happeend to see it for sale on Amazon so I figured ok lets give it a try.

I received it today, unpacked it and rushed out to hook it up to the car.

First and most striking part was how similar it was to the scangauge from look of the display to the placement and the font of the words.

Then it took me nearly seconds to set it up and see what it was capable of.  Now people have complained about innacuracy but this is not the case with this unit.  The one I received is V1.1 and it is exact with the readings on my odometer when it comes to miles or distance traveled.

Second important feature was the fact that the unit can check vital systems in my car (2001 Cadillac Catera) and report wtih OK, NC or NA... I believe they call it readiness test.  I noticed also that it was also able to read my VIN Number.

Thirdly the unit seems to have features that lack on the scangauge.  For example when you are in GAUGE Mode, with the press of the side buttons you can switch between 3 or 4 pages and each one can be customized with whatever gauges you want to view.

So for me at start up I care about engine temp, open/closed loops, ignition, RPMs and intake air temp.  Then once moving I can swap to the next page which shows Speed, Average Fuel Consumption, DTE etc.

Further more there are many other options under trip and settings that appear to be easy to use and well though out form user stand point.

So my first impressions of the unit is that its cheaper then my ScanGauge, its better in many ways, and appears to function as designed.

Further testing and comparisons will be performed and another review will be posted.
summary: MaxiTrip beats ScanGauge in my book.

my 06 Accord 4cyl seems a lot more zippy, responsive and eager than it ever has. once i drive a few tanks on it, i will post if i have any gas milage improvements over conventional oil.

gas milage has improved going from about 23mpg avg to up to 25-26 avg mpg.

the only bad thing i have noticed with this oil that i have also seen mentioned in other reviews is that my car seems to be burning oil a little bit. my car takes about 4.4 quarts according to the manual. I used a larger than stock oil filter (mobil 1 extended) so we will just say it takes 4.5 quarts. after a couple weeks i noticed that the oil was below the bottom dot on the dipstick so i kept adding little sips of oil and then rechecking the level. i eventually i had to add the remainder of the of the jug so within the 1-1.5k initial miles after the change, a top off was needed. about 4k miles after the initial change, another top off was needed. it took almost a whole other quart. a little math here: .5 quarts at the first top off and ill just estimate .7 of a quart at the second top off. at 5k since initial oil change, i am still within the required oil level range on the dipstick. so thats over a quart of burned oil in around 5k miles. my car says about 40% oil life is left. Im going to give it about another 1000-1500 miles or so before i change it and ill update my review again on the color compared to the color of new oil
summary: more zing in your engine AND more mpg

The A3085C is the high capacity version used in Z71 off road variants of the Avalanche 5.3 engines that goes for a $43 premium at dealers. Same physical size as the models without the Z71 package which use the $20 cheaper standard A3086C.......in fact either will fit interchangeably because all models with 5.3s have the same size air filter box.
This high capacity version differs visually from the standard not in pore size but by having many more pleats, i.e. has a much greater surface area of the same filter media....so it takes more dirt to clog it, but under the same conditions should provide less restriction and better breathing than the standard because of the larger surface area. I use them in my wife's non Z71 Avy. Put one in and, and voila!, you have the same induction system as the Z71s.

I have a 2013 base Tacoma that didn't come with INT wiper. This switch is a great fix, a bit pricey. It is a genuine Toyota/Lexus part not a cheap knockoff. (there is a small squeeze clip holding the top steering column  cover, just letting you know so you don't break yours like I did)

reviewText: These sidesteps are made very well. They are very sturdy. I own a 2012 Tacoma Double Cab, and bear in mind that when you receive these, the packaging and instructions will indicate they are for 05-11 Tacomas. I was annoyed by this fact when they arrived at my doorstep. I called the Body Armor folks in Corona, California. I asked them if I was sent the incorrect version and bracket for my 12 Tacoma, they assured me that the brackets do fit the front of 2012 and newer, only 1 screw is used even though there are two on my trucks. I installed them with the help of a friend, and they fit well enough, just not perfect. I wish they included a bracket for newer Tacomas. I also purchased the Step Pads for these as well, separately though. (should be included IMO) They look great but the screws included are ridiculously poor quality, and not long enough to secure the actual pads. Now I need to go in search of black screws/bolts with a nutHappy with the purpose of these Steps for my truck, but very annoyed that they left these small details for the consumer to figure out.
The gauge is spot on, no leaks, great grip on the stem and a great price. I use this on both of my trucks and our RV with no issues at all. If anything changes, I will update this review.
